title.rendered: E3: Changes, Challenges, and What’s Next

content.rendered:
The Electronic Entertainment Expo, or E3, started off as an extension of another wildly popular trade show called Consumer Electronics Show (CES), eventually parting ways from the event. At the time, the Interactive Digital Software Association (IDSA, now known as ESA) decided to announce their own trade show for video games, which would be the E3 we know today. That’s the short of it, at least.

E3 officially started in 1995 and was an “industry only” event, meaning you were required by the ESA to prove you had industry credentials and/or a professional connection to get in. With E3 being such a large, high-profile event – doubled by it being so difficult to get in – E3 held an air of mystique about it, garnering a very enigmatic reputation. It was the “must go” event for all gamers; professionally accredited or not.

“I can’t wait for the PS3 reveal! Everyone’ll love it and it’ll have no problems! Sony is in touch with gamers of 2005!”

I went to my first E3 in 2005. I was newly 20, E3 was my first gaming event, and I was over the moon excited about it. I had spent years prior watching footage on G4TV and wishing I could be Morgan Webb from X-Play covering the event. The coverage on TV and internet could not do justice to the sheer enormity that was E3. Granted, I was young and in love with video games, and, this being my first event, I was feeling pretty cool about garnering a media pass. I have gone nearly every year since, and while nothing compares to your first E3, there is still an air of magic to attending. I have been to dozens of the PAX events, and still E3 was always The One for me. Still, as with any good relationship, things can often end up tumultuous.

There is something to be said about the exclusivity of E3 aiding to its appeal. There is a Psychology behind wanting to sit at the popular table, and for a long time the E3 exclusivity gave a lot of people serious fear of missing out. After all, there’s nothing like a someone saying “you can’t sit with us” to make you want to sit with them – especially if they’re the cool kids.

Stop trying to make the Gameboy Micro happen!

E3 has evolved a lot since its incarnation in 1995, and will no doubt to continue to evolve. Its current announcement in evolution has caused some divisiveness in the community. Recently, a lot of big players have dropped out of E3, including Wargaming, Activision, EA and Disney Interactive – which had always had impressive setups on the show floor. With the departure of these and others leaving, the gaps are filled with companies like Bethesda, who gave its first ever press conference in 2016. To further combat the loss of these players, E3 announced, that for the first time ever, it will sell a limited number of public passes. A lot of E3 alumni were up in arms about this, citing it takes away from the professional atmosphere of the event, fills up the “good hotels”, and that inviting 15,000 from the public to attend will create longer lines and a more congested event. While industry vets were dubious, many felt joy for people who would never be able to go otherwise. While the inclusiveness is wonderful, make no mistake – this is about E3 recouping funds and nothing else.

Personally, I can play both sides, but I keep going back to when I was 20 years old, walking into the convention center and being unbelievably moved and in awe. This will likely be a similar dream come true to nearly 15,000 new attendees and at the end of the day, that’s what’s important to me, personally. Professionally, I will book my hotel yesterday and make sure I flash my press badge like an FBI agent to move in lines to get game coverage.

Current mood: Agent Scully having to show her badge for the 2,837,983,742th time

Will E3 keep this public format? What does this mean for Press/Media registration? Time will tell. This E3 will prove to be a pinnacle play in the show’s future. While selling tickets ($250 bucks a pop!) is a marginally decent way to recoup the loss of bigger companies moving in a different direction, I think it would also be prudent for E3 to rethink its current model. Perhaps it should take a cue from PAX and make it more affordable for indies to come to the show floor. It is hard to deny the importance of indies and the insurmountable growth and popularity of indie studios and their subsequent games, and E3 is out of reach for so many of these up-and-coming titles. Regardless of the direction E3 decides to move in, we’re excited for you first-timers to have an incredible gaming experience.

title.rendered: Player 2 (Please Don’t) Start: The Death Of Single Player Experiences

content.rendered:
How do I feel about single player experiences? In the famous words of the glorious Greta Garbo, when it comes to games, “I just want to be alone”.

Back when I was growing up, gaming was not always affordable for me. I started out on a PC, a seemingly rare thing for gamers apparently.  However, keeping up with the Joneses (Gates?) was costly, so my PC became unplayable within a few short years. I was still playing the NES well into the mid ’90s, but only because the 16 bit generation was slightly out of my family’s disposable income reach.

It wasn’t all that bad, though – I enjoyed playing and replaying the few games I had for the NES, and since I was still just starting elementary school I didn’t really know what I was missing anyway. I didn’t mind just playing the NES by myself for hours on end, focused on completing the seemingly impossible goal of beating Super Mario Bros. 3 without my dad’s help.

It wasn’t like that forever though; we had a few good Christmases. Occasionally, something amazing would fall off the back of Santa’s sleigh and land under the Christmas tree. On those rare happy times, I’d receive a new console, like the N64 (which came bundled with DK64) and the PS2 (which was gifted to me alongside Kingdom Hearts).

Like before, my preference for single player sessions dominated each console and, ultimately, my game choice. I gravitated more towards RPGs and away from the FPS and fighting games my friends preferred. Where my peers seemingly only desired a social gaming experience, I wanted to be immersed in a story for hours of solitary amusement. While my buddies played Goldeneye, Doom, Mario Kart, and Street Fighter, I preferred Mario 64, Katamari Damacy, Final Fantasy, and Civilization.

Civilization: a historically accurate good time!

Of course, there were some games I played with friends (or were more at least forced to, I should say). Pokemon required fellow trainers to complete a full Pokedex. Mario Party offered hours of entertainment. I played both of these titles with friends more because I wanted to play the game and less because I wanted to play with any given person. Not that I hated my friends or anything, but if I wanted to be social I would rather ride bikes or play basketball. Video games were…y’know. My thing.

20 years later and I still play the exact same way. I stick to single player games and rarely venture out of that arena. There’s just something about the single player experience that feels effortless and relaxing. Civilization, Final Fantasy, and Katamari are still staples in my gaming library, but so are games like Skyrim, Phoenix Wright, and Saints Row.

Okay but honestly, you should all have this game.

The difference between now and then, however, is that the single player experience is no longer an attractive selling point. In fact, the opposite is usually true: games, especially those of the AAA variety, are consistently being marketed as multiplayer and co-op experiences. Even freemium games like Pokemon Go are hailed as revolutionary for getting people off their couches and out into the open with *gasp* other people.

Coupled with the fact that sales of traditionally amazing franchises, like Final Fantasy, are dwindling. Of course, this is the fault of poor content; nevertheless, single player games are seeing dwindling sales overall. This certainly can’t bode well for those of us that prefer the genres dedicated to this experience. Are we – the single player gamers – a dying breed?

Now I know I’m not alone in being…well alone. There’s gotta be plenty of gamers out there like me. Gamers that prefer the quiet solitude of retreating to their console or PC at the end of the day and blocking everyone – and I mean everyone – out for the rest of the evening.

So where does that leave the gamer that doesn’t like co-op?

Obviously RPGs and other single player games exist, but they don’t sell like games that provide co-op experiences such as Call of Duty. While this hasn’t stopped other non co-op games from coming to fruition, it does pose a potential problem in the future. If money talks, and it does, the likelihood of single player games being the powerhouse that they once were seems bleak.

In addition to a possible dwindling of games, there are these things called “communities”. They’ve sprung up within the last decade or so and are completely and utterly foreign to me. While the EquityArcade discord is pretty freakin’ sweet, I’ll admit this is a new, unfamiliar venture for me. Yet this is exactly what the trend is going towards – community, inclusion, friends…social gaming. Not that I don’t want it but…at the same time…

Hate is a strong word, but I really, really, really don’t like them…in my games.

In the future, I imagine games will focus more and more on social experiences. There will be more co-op abilities and more gimmicks to get people moving. Even games like CIV are becoming social; the next step would be to continue in this vein.

And there I’ll be, an old lady gamer, surrounding myself with the last remaining handful of single player games. I’ll be charging my vintage 3DS and shaking my fist at the newest generation, bemoaning the cursed co-op.

Because just like the single player game, those that like them will be doomed to either join or die alone.

title.rendered: Using Video Games to Buffer a Breakup

content.rendered:
Heartbreak. We’ve all experienced it. That hallowing, out of body feeling when grieving for a person who turned out to be only a temp in your life. The realization that all that emotional effort, money spent, and time lost was all in hopes for a future never met. Yet we keep on doing this to ourselves. Statistically, most relationships don’t work out, yet we are an industrious species. We are hopeful, romantic, lonely and confused…or maybe just gluttons for punishment. Whatever the root of the intrinsic desire to couple up may be, we’ve all been on either end of a breakup and we all cope differently.

Cope is defined very simply as “the struggle to deal” and it’s safe to say the struggle is real with matters of the heart. Everyone has different coping mechanisms, but at its core the objective is the same: distraction. I think it is relatively safe to say that within our community, one of the most notable and effective ways to “struggle to deal” is with video games.

Get this man some vidya – stat!

I had a friend reach out and tell me that after a really bad breakup, he turned to Halo 3. He played this game for months, seeking solace in the gameplay for distraction and the community of players online for companionship. To this day, he returns to Halo 3 specifically whenever he is feeling a bit out of sorts. I found this in particular to be interesting.

Unfortunately, I had to begrudgingly cull my long distance relationship after the realization he had no future in particular in mind. Breaking up with someone you’re not necessarily unhappy with is a unique situation, and one that is very new to me. I am struggling. I don’t want this, but this is my reality, so now I’ve got to fist fight this struggle for the next couple weeks, months, etc. My story isn’t important, but my coping mechanisms post-breakup are.

“Take two of these and call me…which game you playin’? Skyrim? I’ll see you in six years.” – best doctor ever.

After I broke it off, I went into the an emotional equivalent of Silent Hill. I cried a lot, listened to shit music and wrote my thoughts out, albeit poorly. This isn’t necessarily unique, but there has been a pattern regarding breakups for me that I find interesting after my friend told me his Halo 3 coping story. Right after the heartbreak, I had this overwhelming desire to play Final Fantasy IX. Why this game in particular? I spent some time thinking about this, and came to the realization that this is my game that feels like home. I played through Final Fantasy IX from start to finish, savoring every disc, during a tumultuous time with my family. This game brought me great comfort, and is the game I turn to replay often; suspiciously around times of heartache. Much like my friend and Halo 3 – we likely all have a game that comforts us.

Currently, I am starting my traditional post-heartmurder replay through Final Fantasy IX. Additionally, I’m playing a lot of Overwatch and a few Indie Games like Owl Boy and Rogue Legacy. If you don’t have a video game that feels like “home” yet, I can almost promise you that you will. Regardless, we as a community of gamers turn to gaming as an obvious solution in distraction and entertainment – doubly so when we feel alone in this unpredictable world. We are lucky to have a community of people to virtually rest our heads on through these rough times. This community is constantly growing at a Sonic pace (see what we did there), and through communicable advances like Discord, Twitch, and video game-centric events, these friends are more real and subsequently offer a much warmer solace when our hearts are destroyed on some Final Fantasy VII Aerith level shit. This is yet another testament to how important video games are.

If you’re feeling sad, for whatever reason, I’ve compiled a few “comfy” games that are guaranteed to make you feel some kind of way:

Journey

While it is debated whether or not that video games could be considered art, games like ThatGameCompany’s Journey put up quite a visually stunning fight. While the main campaign is considered relatively short in comparison to most games, it effortlessly delivers a more thought-provoking and emotional connection throughout. Journey is unique in its simplicity.

With no memory or distinct direction within the game, you are simply shown your destination – a bright light at the top of a very distant mountain. Your destination is nearly always in view, acting as both a map and a monument of motivation. Every play-through is so extraordinarily different and emotionally compelling, giving this game a true sense of fortitude among other current blockbuster games. This game lives up to its namesake, showing us that it, and life, is truly all about the journey – not the destination.

The Legend of Zelda: The WindWaker

Arguably the IP’s cheekiest and most whimsical installment, Nintendo’s Legend of Zelda: Windwaker offers a bright, cell-shaded journey through all the classic temples, plus some soothing high-seas shenanigans. Exploring villages alone in Windwaker is therapeutic; you meet a lively cast of characters, and the game dialogue is sure to make you laugh.

The Legend of Zelda series has been around since the bulk of us were kids, and in that virtue alone it offers a sense of nostalgic comfort. If anything at all, start a fresh game and classically throw some chickens around.

 

Papo & Yo

Papo & Yo is an emotional journey brought to us by Minority studio. This adventure game has light, easy on the brain puzzle mechanics and is set in the Imagination of our protagonist, Quirco. With lots of South American visuals and comforts, you traverse an imaginative landscape with a monster in tow. This monster…aptly named “Monster” isn’t so much a companion as the physical manifestation of Quirco’s emotions throughout the game.

Navigating this game through Quirco’s imagination allows for some very fun and interesting in-game mechanics, but the heart and soul of this game is the quest in which Quirco comes to understand his Monster.

 

To The Moon

Freebird Games has delivered such a monumental feat in story-telling that you almost forget it’s a game. That’s a good thing. To the Moon is an indie adventure RPG about two doctors traversing through the memories of a dying man to fulfill his last wish. Are you crying yet? You follow two doctors, equipped with technology that’s somewhere in the realm of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind and the “Sand Junipero” episode of Black Mirror.

“The technology requires the doctors to step into the memories of the patient, which are reconstructed as interactive scenes. The doctors then gradually traverse backwards through memories of the patient’s life until they reach childhood — at which point, the wish of the patient in present time would be transferred over. Along with the doctors’ influence, the patient (as a child) could then lead an entirely different life inside their head, working toward and fulfilling their dying wish themselves.”

To The Moon has much more in store for the player, and I personally encourage you to spend some time with it.

 

What are some of the games you like to rinse through when feeling sad or down? Let us know in the comments section – we’re itching to play more!

title.rendered: Mob Mentality vs. Anonymous: Spot The Difference

content.rendered:
Mob mentality, often described also as “herd mentality” is a term used to describe how people are influenced by their peers to adopt certain behaviors. Think of it as low-key and often times subliminal peer pressure. You’re part of a group of peers with one steadfast idea, motive or opinion in common. Before you can think for yourself, you’re part of the decentralized decision making. We’ve all fallen to the whim of mob mentality on different moral and ethical levels; there is a social psychology behind how and why. The brain has a tendency to go into a sort of auto-pilot and suppress one’s personal moral compass when in large groups. Why does the brain do this?

This mentality goes back to our deepest, basest, most instinctual roots. When you are solitary or in small, familiar groups (family, friends, Tuesday yoga class, etc) your brain adheres to its “default” morality settings. In a large group setting, your brain’s subliminal desire to fit in switches from “me” to “us” or “them” and is often exacerbated by anonymity. When an individual feels their identity is concealed enough in a group to mask their specific actions as an individual, the brain subconsciously – and sometimes consciously – justifies this behavior. The innate notion that you are protected by a group with no risk of individual repercussion so easily melts away rational judgement and shifts the user into a completely different consciousness; it’s almost a conditioned reflex. Mob Mentality has been around for ages; some pertinent historical examples are The French Revolution, Holocaust, The Salem Witch Trials and our most recent and expansive example…The Internet.

Mindlessly following the herd? RADICAL!

If you’ve ever been on the internet, you’ve either been initiated in or victim of mob mentality. We all witness it in varying degrees on a day-to-day basis. It’s gotten to the point where it has become such an ingrained aspect of our daily routine that our brain doesn’t even register that it’s problematic. The internet, despite all it’s done for the world as a whole, has become a breeding ground for exacerbating mob mentality through social media, internet forums like Reddit and 4chan, and even inciting mob ideas through questionable and uninformed “news” articles. You ever scroll through Facebook and see an absurd article titled something like “Breaking News: Scientists Say Water is Bad For You!” and you see 3,462 comments of people arguing that the article has a point? Yeah, that.

Unfortunately, these articles are so prevalent and the mob behavior within the comments is so second nature that you either participate or keep scrolling. While these Facebook dumpster fires are harmless and entertaining enough, not all internet mob mentality is; in fact, it can become extremely dangerous and detrimental to people and their actual lives outside of the main-frame. How is mob mentality made worse via the internet? Two key factors play a part here: Anonymity and Dissociation.

And Matrix effects circa 2000

I’d like to clarify that I am not targeting or discussing the “Anon” force nor their rallied agenda. It’s safe to say most of us are familiar with “Anon” and their combined hacking forces, and while there is some debate on if they do more harm than good, any force that uses their combined efforts to shut down well over 50 child pornography sites, hold animal abusers accountable, fight for LGBT rights, fight against racism, expose government injustice – the list of positive ethical intentions goes on – is fighting for the greater good (in my opinion). Perhaps one of the few examples of mob mentality focused on a primarily ethical high-road.

Unfortunately, where things get dicey is individual users coming together in online forums or social medias and losing all inhibition, disassociating from their “real world” as they settle down in front of a screen. Disassociation is a spectrum and can not be used as a blanket term in regards to online trolling and mob mentality. Trolling as well is on a spectrum; from harassing a friend on Facebook for sharing that “Water Is Bad For You” article all the way to bullying someone into ending their life. Trolling can be innocent enough – you’re looking for a laugh so you poke fun at something online, respond exclusively in memes and call it a night.

Black Mirror Season 3 Ep 3, anyone?

While it may be obvious how anonymity aids and abets trolls online, there may be a much larger psychological behavioral background at work here. Within the Dissociation spectrum is something Psychologists call “Disinhibition Effect” which is defined as “the reduction or abandonment in remote electronic communications of those social restrictions and inhibitions that would arise in normal face-to-face communication”. Anonymity makes every difference, and unfortunately, this frees some to partake in some pretty egregious behavior. When you are, for all intents and purposes, invisible among a community, you’ll do and say whatever to find acceptance among the herd; because this acceptance is much harder to find offline. We’re all victim to the carnal desire to fit in.

On Wednesdays we wear pink. Every other day we’re horrendously shitty to each other.

“That anonymity works wonders for the disinhibition effect. When people have the opportunity to separate their actions from their real world and identity, they feel less vulnerable about opening up. Whatever they say or do can’t be directly linked to the rest of their lives. They don’t have to own their behavior by acknowledging it within the full context of who they “really” are. When acting out hostile feelings, the person doesn’t have to take responsibility for those actions. In fact, people might even convince themselves that those behaviors “aren’t me at all.” In psychology this is called ‘dissociation.’” 

John Suler, Psychology of the Digital Age

Where do we draw the line in the proverbial sand between casual internet trolling and harmful mob mentality? Why does the internet exacerbate this behavior so fervently? What can we do about it? Are we all just innate assholes and just needed the internet’s gift of pure, unadulterated anonymity within its communities to bring this realization to fruition?

Unfortunately, the psychology is there and within us all, and we can’t do much of anything to control behavioral disturbances on the internet; what you can do is take accountability for your actions and be excellent to each other.

and party on, dudes!

title.rendered: Online Friends & Saying Goodbye: Coping With Loss In The Gaming Community

content.rendered:
If you’re like the average Millenial/Gen X-er, a good portion of your time is spent online in some capacity. If you’re a gamer, that tends to go doubly so. A lot of gamers play co-op games with their online friends, join guilds through games like World of Warcraft, or frequent online gaming forums. Through these activities, we make friends with people we will likely never meet in “real life”. The capacity to make friends within Cyber Space is a testament to how something once shamed as an anti-social, indoor-kid hobby is actually a unique exercise in socialization for a community of people with one shared interest; it’s one of the many reasons why gaming is so valuable.

As a gamer, you’ve likely made online friends via gaming through some avenue whether it be guildmates, a forum friend, or you played a fire match with a stranger and added each other to subsequently then jump into games every night after work, etc. However you met them, this community offers a wealth of friendship that is only growing that sense of camaraderie through current gaming phenomena such as Twitch and esports.

As life does, it gives and it takes…and it quite often takes. Death can draft in like a breeze and take people from us so swiftly, leaving in its wake many esoteric feelings of morose confusion. When this kind of loss happens to a friend or family member outside the realm of Cyber Space, we grieve and our social circles understand. We are offered sincere, relatable condolences in droves. But what about when that person, for all intents and purposes, only existed to you? Online friends who you never knew in person but connected with just like anyone else within your immediate vicinity? It’s hard to explain the importance of a bond that wasn’t physically tangible to outsiders of your virtual world. How do you grieve? Who do you talk to? Are you justified in feeling such a loss so deeply?

The answer is simple: yes, of course! Losing someone whom you’ve never met is a tumultuous experience, but at the end of the day...a loss is a loss, and we are indentured to our late online friends to feel it in its entirety in memoriam to the companionship and time given to us by them.

When I was 14 years old, I had a Gateway desktop PC gifted to me by my father. I spent my time in Final Fantasy AOL chatrooms, scrolling through GameFAQS.com, and writing in my Livejournal. Yes, that’s right, Livejournal.

One of my first Livejournal friends was a kid who went by the alias “Ruxpin”. At the time, the friendship may have been considered unusual, as making online friends was still actively discouraged. But he, Ruxpin from Canada, and I, Pryde from Florida, unassumingly maintained a friendship through Livejournal for years, often times playing games of Starcraft together and causing trouble in IIRC groups. We trolled the Something Awful forums together, and when World of Warcraft came out in 2004, we joined the Something Awful guild “Goon Squad” on the Mal’Ganis server; he an Undead Rogue and I a Troll Warrior.

We put years into the game together, spending many late nights talking on Ventrillo. He became friendly with some of my first boyfriends through our time spent playing games, always playing the part of the protective older brother. It was a relationship I treasured dearly.

Eventually, I fell off World of Warcraft and my life became pretty chaotic for a few years. I moved around a lot and was not online and in touch as I used to be. Every few months he would call me to “check in” and make sure I was okay – something I can’t say anyone else has ever done for me. Once my life settled down, we got back into our gaming routine and would often chat on Skype. We made plans several times to meet at events, but life would happen and it never worked out.

I spoke to him one night via Facebook Messenger while I lay in bed. He had a job opportunity in Florida that he wanted to take. I encouraged him, offered help, and said goodnight.

I awoke the next morning to see condolences of his passing scribed generously on his Facebook page.

After 16 years, I wondered now who would call and check up on me.

The perception that online relationships are somehow less real than their physical counterparts exemplifies what Nathan Jurgenson, a New York-based sociologist and researcher for the messaging platform Snapchat, calls “digital dualism.” Contemporary identities and relationships are no more or less authentic in either space. “We’re coming to terms with there being just one reality and digital is part of it, not any less real or true,” Jurgenson said. “What you do online and what you do face-to-face are completely interwoven.”

Your Internet Friends Are Real

I was absolutely crushed by the death of my dear friend – someone who had been with me through the many ups and downs in my life. But like the uniqueness of our time spent together, the grieving process that I experienced was also one that I was not accustomed to.

As a species, we understand death despite its heart-wrenching effects – the person you’ve come to love and care deeply about is now gone from your life, leaving a void as big as the space they created. The loss of online friends, however, is anomalous in how after the passing, we are haunted by their online digital footprint. This haunting can take many forms, whether it be their social media accounts, gamertags, YouTube videos, Twitch VOD’s, logging into Battle.net and seeing their tag “last logged in….” – these reminders are simultaneously beautiful and brutal.

At face value, nothing has changed on your end; after all, the accounts are still there, and it’s through those accounts that you knew them. But the knowledge that your online friends are no longer behind those accounts lodges itself in the gut, weighing us down despite looking right at their profile photo and seeing no on-screen difference than when they were alive.

It’s difficult to navigate the rocky waters of losing our online friends – someone you care for, yet never met. Hopefully, you can turn to the community to see if other people are grieving with you, but often times this is a lonely undertaking. Turning to people in your daily routine for condolences is usually not a fruitful experience; it can often be unintentionally patronizing or dismissive because this kind of loss does not compute with them. This dismissive solace can be polarizing, but you are never alone. A loss is a loss, and your feelings of grief are valid.

While everyone grieves differently, there are a lot of therapeutic ways to displace these feelings in a positive way:

  • Send flowers and/or condolences to the family if that’s an option. Let them know they were cared about in a community beyond their knowledge.
  • Stream in their honor. If you have a game together, it’s nice to rinse through your feelings by revisiting those memories. If they had a game they were looking forward to, stream that.
  • Adopt their gamer tag for characters in future games to aid their online legacy.
  • Participate in a charity in their honor. Depending on how our person has passed, there is likely a charity for it. Suicide Prevention, Cancer, Drug Abuse, Accidents, etc.
  • Raise money towards the greater good in their name, whether this is via crowdfunding, an event or streaming. Running an Extra-Life charity in their name is one I personally would recommend.
  • Write. You don’t have to be a writer to write. If you don’t write often, I feel this exercise is hugely beneficial, in fact. Write an article, write in a journal, write a letter directly to them. The brain goes into a different mode when writing, working certain areas often not triggered during any other task. Writing helps elicit not only creative thought but emotional response, allowing writing to be a hugely cathartic tool while grieving.
  • Grief Forums. If you feel you can’t (or don’t want to) talk about this with anyone in your immediate life, there are many wonderful grief forums out there that you can find an unbelievable amount of warmth from. Sound lame? It’s not, I promise you. Here are some great ones: Compassionate Friends, Online Grief Support as well as copious subreddits for grieving, some tailor-made for particular losses and causes of death. Here’s Reddit: Grief Support to get started with a more general one.
  • Listen. You can download Podcasts about grief or online friends if you find comfort in listening to someone while you go through your day to day.
  • If it’s your thing, get a tattoo! You could say it’s my thing. 

Thankfully, we live in a time where we are on the precipice of online friendships becoming the norm. The line between “real life” and our online space becomes increasingly more blurred as the years pass and the attitude towards the internet changes dramatically. We have both feet firmly planted in the digital age; and the stigma of online friendship is slowly washing away and integrating into societal norm. How lucky we are to so easily make these connections and friendships; the ability to create and maintain friendships with people all over the world is becoming one of gaming’s fundamentals. At the end of the day, we should remember how fortunate we truly are to cultivate these friendships through such a monumentally unique community, and we should continue to honor them when they leave us.

If you or someone you know is having a hard time through the grieving process or anything where they need help, please don’t be afraid to reach out. Please visit PsychCentral for a list of pertinent Hotlines – support is out there for you.

title.rendered: By the Numbers: Call of Duty’s Massive Sales

content.rendered:
Call of Duty: one of the few places where mean-spirited 13-year olds can talk shit to adults. “F*cking n00b, I’ll beat yo ass 1v1 IRL lehgo,” they scream in high-pitched & cracking voices, the little bastards (who care little about Call of Duty sales, common decency, or of their future in general, honestly).

Joke’s on you kid – you’ll inherit a far more broken economy and global warming will have really taken its toll when you’re an adult!

But you have to accept such insults, because if you play CoD, you’re going to come across the entire spectrum of humanity. Adults, rude children, unintelligible foreigners, anonymous celebrities, drunk grandmothers and the rest. This is because, if the sales figures are any indication, damn near every gamer on the plane towns the games.

Let’s start with an impressive yet simple statistic: Call of Duty is the 4th best selling video game franchise in history. Now, if this were the Olympics, that placing would mean lifelong crippling disappointment. But when you look at the three titans in front of CoD, it’s hard to be upset: Tetris, Mario, and Pokemon.

Although sometimes gold, silver, and bronze wipe themselves out and 4th becomes 1st, so…there’s that.

That’s it. Only those three series have outsold Call of Duty in all of gaming history. And each is significantly older than CoD — Tetris and Mario by almost two decades –giving them many more years to earn over Call of Duty sales.

For more context, CoD has outsold Final Fantasy, The Sims, Grand Theft Auto, and Need for Speed by wide margins. And those are all top 10 franchises in their own right; megahits like Sonic, Halo, and Madden don’t even make that list.

The raw numbers are where this really gets fun. Since 2003, Call of Duty sales total roughly 250 million units. That’s one copy for every twenty-eight people on Earth. If every one of those people played for just ten hours (which is an absurdly conservative estimate), the world has logged over 285,000 years on CoD. If you go that far back on Earth’s timeline, Homo sapiens hadn’t even evolved yet.

The fries you ate for lunch from McDonald’s, on the other hand, preceded Homo Sapiens and even Homo Habilis..

Let’s turn that number into dollars. If you total up the revenue from every CoD game, you land right around 9.7 billion dollars — or with the zeroes included, which is always more impressive, $9,700,000,000. And if you include add-ons and expansions, that total jumps to $11 billion.

Roll that back into the individual titles – CoD has released a new game annually like clockwork – and it’s still hard to wrap your head around the numbers. By the end of 2015, five individual titles had broken the $1 billion mark, and it’s believed that the latest installment, Black Ops 3, has passed that threshold since.

It’s not clear whether Black Ops 3 has become the best-selling single title in the franchise (up-to-date numbers aren’t available, but 2011’s Modern Warfare 3 is listed at $1.22 billion). It was, however, certainly trending that way from day one: the games 24-hour sales numbers hit $400 million. In one day, CoD generated revenue that outpaced the annual GDP of 10 Pacific Island nations.

Or you can compare that number to a parallel entertainment venture: movies. The largest 24-hour box office take for a film was Star Wars: The Force Awakens, at a measly 120 million, only 30% of Black Ops 3 taking. And if you look at total box office sales, Modern Warfare 3 beat every single movie of 2016. That’s right – even Deadpool, Batman vs. Superman, The Jungle Book, Zootopia, and Captain America: Civil War didn’t sell as much..

Honestly they’re just fighting for the scraps at this point.

All this is to say, Call of Duty is big business. Like, country-dwarfing, entertainment-industry-dominating big. So naturally, Call of Duty sales will dwarf the rest of us for all of time and eternity. If the CoD franchise were actually playing CoD, it’d be that thirteen-year old getting multiple 10-kill streaks per game and mocking the rest of us over the mic, “F*cking n00bs.”

title.rendered: Indie Game of the Week: Dead by Daylight

content.rendered:
If for some reason you haven’t already played Dead by Daylight, you couldn’t possibly have picked a more appropriate time to start. Behaviour Digital released the aptly titled “Halloween” this Tuesday. It’s the second chapter in the multiplayer horror game featuring none other than Halloween’s very own Michael Myers and sounds like a recipe for success given the overwhelmingly positive reaction people have had to the original.

Behavior, the Montreal team formerly known as A2M (read: Artificial Mind & Movement) teamed up with Starbreeze Studios for Dead by Daylight. They boast big names on their resumes, like EA, Disney Interactive and Konami, and are currently partnered with Cloud Imperium for the much anticipated Star Citizen.

Behavior also prepared a pretty significant patch earlier this week in anticipation of the DLC to come. One of the studio’s strong suits has been their implementation of community feedback throughout development. This is a rare treat amongst game developers these days, but definitely one you’ll only see in the indie game development community.

Most of the feedback is soaked in urine, but still, they listen.

We started playing back while it was Early Access in July. I’m a horrific (read: hilarious) killer – I’m scared for the victims, so I don’t actually want to catch them; ironic, because whenever I play as a survivor I instinctively look to taunt the killer. What I think Dead by Daylight does best, however, is actually the Bloodweb – their leveling up tree. It’s strange because I don’t normally fuss over customizations or upgrades. I think it’s the fact that the survivors are so similar to a Depraved from Dark Souls that I obsess over whatever advantages the Bloodweb will grant me. Considering the fact that survivors die repeatedly, perhaps there are more similarities than previously thought.

With the second chapter comes new characters and new perks. Perks are pretty necessary and, if you’re playing as a survivor, they will save your life from time to time. The nature of the relationship between killer and survivor draw out the perks. For example, when survivor Laurie Strode uses “Decisive Strike”, she fends off the Killer. To add to the creepy atmosphere, the perks read like a director’s commentary from the 1978 film. It also helps that the new map is a recreation of that spooky neighborhood set in Haddonfield, NJ. Strangely enough, I’ve seen that house on a Hollywood tour many years ago. Go figure.

I’ve never been one for costumes but boy let me tell you do I love candy.

This game also boasts something that other indie titles often struggle to offer – replayability. Because the game is multiplayer with up to five friends with two distinct experiences, the game will have fans for a long time. Not bad for such an affordable title!

Considering that Halloween is just around the corner, this really is the perfect indie title to celebrate the season. Or Christmas season since it’ll make a great gift. Or to just enjoy because you like scary things. Whatever, it’s good for any occasion. You can try to survive on Steam for only $19.99.

title.rendered: 5 Pixelated Presidents We’re Desperate Enough To Vote For

content.rendered:
If you’re like us, you knew about the presidential debate last night. If you’re also like us, you actively avoided it because your blood pressure is already way too high. It’s not that we don’t like the candidates or anything, we just…don’t like the candidates. Or anything. We’ll take former presidents over these guys. Even presidents of other countries. Trudeau, anyone?

“Oh, Canada…our home and newfound land…”

It doesn’t matter who you’re voting for in defiance of another candidate, you’re just not excited for November 8th…or November 28th for some of you. But why? It’s not because politics are boring this year – they’ve been anything but. No, the truth is, the candidates are missing a little something that makes us feel…alive. Invigorated. Stimulated. And other quasi-sexual adjectives.

We just miss getting the tinglies when it comes to our presidents and Election Day, so we took it upon ourselves as part of our patriotic duty to round up a list of the decent-enough presidents that video games have ever given us. The Founding Fathers would be most pleased that we’re coming up with imaginary alternatives to our bizarro bipartisan politics, so be a true American and read about our preferred pixelated presidents for 2016.

1. President Ronnie (Bad Dudes vs. Dragon Ninja)

“Rampant ninja related crimes these days… Whitehouse is not the exception…”

Those chilling words preceded the unfortunate kidnapping of President Ronnie, the beloved Commander in Chief that is totally not Ronald Reagan at all.

Perhaps he’s not the strongest president to start off with – after all, he does spend most of the game being kidnapped. But think about who kidnapped him for just a second. It wasn’t your average POTUS-nappers or anything like that – it was the nefarious Japanese hitman cooperative known as Dragon Ninja. That name alone should tell you that the Secret Service was no match for their Pres-napping skills, and Radical Ronnie had no choice but to go along with their evil schemes.

But it’s okay – the Bad Dudes save President Ronnie and, in a total broTUS move, he offers to take them out for Burgers. Talk about great domestic policy – what a great guy!

2. President John Henry Eden (Fallout 3)

Now we know what you’re thinking – “wasn’t John Henry Eden the bad guy from the game?”

Yes. Yes he was. But at the same time he was a mindless, emotionless machine. He didn’t let things like pettiness, anger, and contempt cloud his judgement because he didn’t have those feelings. He just operated on logic because that’s what computers do. And if there’s anything we need right now, it’s logic – something machines have in droves and the current presidential elections definitely lack.

Besides, it’s not like he got us into the mess of nuclear fallout in the first place, and he did his best to clean up the country after President Dick Richardson’s meltdown in Fallout 2. So he can be forgiven when he explodes once thrown through a logic loop a la Wanderer. Can’t blame the com-POTUS – happens to the best of us.

3. President The Boss (Saints Row IV)

If you haven’t played Saints Row IV, stop reading this article right now and go play. Now. Bonus points if you play Saints Row III while you’re at it. We won’t wait for you to finish because you’re just going to be playing for the next few weeks and we don’t want to bore the rest of the readers that came prepared.

Anyway, the boss is perhaps the greatest president to ever grace the hallowed halls of the White House. Sure, between punching random congressmen and getting the entire Earth blown up they certainly don’t seem that way, but the boss did rip the evil alien overlord Zinyak’s head off his body with the spine intact, so that…that kind of wins the most boss-ass president award right there. Plus the boss single-handedly defused a live missile and then gained the ability to fly, time-travel, and use a dubstep gun, soooo…yeah. #Boss2016

4. Any Cat Presidents (Cat President: A More Purr-fect Union)

Okay, so maybe you think we’ve lost it. And we probably have. But we think that at this point, any of the cats from Cat President: A More Purr-fect Union would be simply purr-fect. And yes, we are a-meows-ed by our puns. There probably wouldn’t be any wars because cats just sleep all day. Cats don’t know what to do with money because they don’t understand the human economy, so they wouldn’t embezzle anything. Everyone will watch their speeches since they’d be cat videos. Also, they’re cute. So there’s that.

Only drawback we can see is that they might claw the furniture or pee around the White House when they feel slightly threatened. Much better than the current political climate for sure.

5. President Reagan (Reagan/Gorbachev)

Not to be confused with President Ronnie, President Reagan actually existed. Like in real life. Your dad probably still has a boner for him. Nicknamed “The Great Communicator”, Ronald Reagan lives up to that nickname by trading hilarious quips with his best pal, Gorby in this little indie gem. It opens up with the Reaganator being a total fuckin’ BAMF and breaking into an isolated rebel jail to spring Gorbachev from his cell. And that totally was a thing that happened – according to the game at least. He doesn’t run as fast as his Russian Rival, but that doesn’t stop him from picking locks and swinging a katana around like the badass he is/was.

We could totally use a guy like that around the White House these days – all problems could be solved with a katana and snarky comments.

 

So…what’cha think? Would you vote for any of these presidents to lead our fine country? Or would you rather have the current candidates take a whack at it? Let us know in the comments!

title.rendered: 10 Extremely Dark Video Games That Will Probably Scar You

content.rendered:
(Warning: while we don’t give away too many major plot points and or any surprise endings to these dark video games, we obviously couldn’t keep an article of this nature completely spoiler free. So, much like pooping in a public bathroom, proceed at your own risk.)

The word ‘game’ implies fun. Seriously — I just checked Merriam-Webster’s Dictionary to confirm that was true. Because after digesting what each of these video ‘games’ was really about, I was doubting my grasp on this simple English word.

Of course, most video game titles are playful and lighthearted. Which makes sense – developers want you to enjoy yourself, so you’ll buy more bullshit overpriced DLCs stuff from them in the future.

But sometimes, creators go a different direction. They deliver a title that tackles difficult and depressing topics, or contains emotional depth of a potentially uncomfortable nature. Or sometimes, they just want to f*ck with you.

Ladies and Gentlemen, Hideo Kojima.

Whatever the case, this is what happens when brilliant game developers go grim. Check out our nominees (read: undisputed master list) for extremely dark video games – maybe even the darkest video games ever:

 

1. To the Moon

It won damn near every award given to indie games in 2011, and yet, as one reviewer put it, “How do I explain why it’s brilliant without spoiling what makes it so?”

In this world, doctors have the power to alter memories for dying people so they can pass without regrets. Two doctors are tasked with fulfilling a man’s request to ‘remember’ visiting the moon, but to do this, they have to pour through all the real (and often tragic) memories of his life. And thus unfolds one of the most beloved, thoughtful stories in gaming history. Truly a unique experience that will definitely stick with you for life.

There’s not much traditional ‘gameplay’, but to use the cliché – you’ll laugh, you’ll cry, and you’ll walk away at the end with a moved heart – before one final twist.

 

2. NIER

This 2010 spinoff of the uber-popular Drakengard series received a mixed bag of reviews at the time. Some claimed the graphics weren’t up to par and that the gameplay wasn’t as strong as it should have been, but it’s beloved by quite a few for all the right reasons.

What’s made it stand the test of time, more so than most other RPGs, is the storytelling. Your overarching goal is to save your dying daughter, which is grim enough. But many love this game for the way every momentary triumph is immediately trumped by more tragedy, and the mastery with which the developers get you invested in the characters. Prepare to have your heartstrings pulled.

 

3. Mother 3

This Japanese bestseller was a marked turn from its two prequels. While thought provoking, the first two were better known for their humor; the third went a different, grimmer direction.

The game opens with the death of your character’s wife, and without giving anything away, she’s not going to be the only one. But other characters will make you legitimately angry – a monkey that’s electrocuted and threatened with his girlfriends death? A father constantly calling his son a moron? And none of this is to mention the more subtle social commentary that runs throughout. The cartoonish graphics do little to convince anyone this game is for children.

 

4. One Chance (WARNING: video contains spoilers!)

The name of the game is literal: you can only play it once. Try to reload it in your browser and you’ll simply be dropped back off at whatever ending you’ve already accomplished.

Which thematically matches the plot: you’re the scientist who just accidentally released a ‘cure for cancer’ that is instead wiping out the world’s population in just six days time. The question is, what do you do with your final days on Earth? And with only ‘One Chance’ to play, the emotional weight of your often-brutal decisions stick with you in a way no other game can achieve. Talk about taking dark video games to the extreme!

So…if you only had one chance, what would you do?

 

5. Bioshock: Infinite

Probably the most successful title on this list (in America, anyway), and I don’t think anyone who’s played it through has any illusions about this being a chipper, happy experience.

The story opens without giving you much information, save that your mercenary-type character must capture a strange girl in a floating city to ‘wipe away the debt’. The next dozen or so hours of gameplay slowly unfold a story that will by turns make you sad, mad, and confused, and just when you think you’ve got a handle on where the ending’s headed, it throws you for three more loops. The word ‘betrayal’ comes to mind.

Are you one of the few people who haven’t played this game yet? You want a popular title that’ll legitimately give you the feels? Here it is.

 

6. Silent Hill 2

If you’re only vaguely familiar with this title, you may think we’re making a mistake. A survival horror game featuring uncountable monsters trying to kill you? That’s a horror thriller, and while they’re awesome in their own right, they’re not the kind of ‘dark’ we’re talking about here.

Except this one is. The second Silent Hill is revered not for it’s excellent gameplay or stunning graphics – gamers remember it for the storytelling. Your character receives a letter from his dead wife that lures him to a strange, hellish town. But the subtle way the plot unfolds, and how you learn the twisted backstories explaining exactly what’s happened to all the characters you’re encountering (including yourself) make this one of the greatest dark video games ever.

 

7. Legend of Zelda: Majora’s Mask

A familiar complaint about long running series is that they sometimes stay too, well, familiar. That argument is pretty valid with most Zelda titles.

Not Majora’s Mask. It starts off sad – Link lost and depressed in a new land – and it only gets darker from there. From the stories of the people he encounters to a truly heartbreaking ending, it’s like nothing else in the Zelda series. Which makes the entire experience even more powerful. Try to play this one without feeling lost, lonely, and miserable yourself. If you are able to, you may not have a soul and you might want to get that checked out.

 

8. Sad Satan

In a meta sense, this ‘game’ is even creepier because no one’s totally sure what it is:

Someone uploaded a video of themselves doing a play-through to Youtube (above) claiming they found the game on the deep web. In it, the player walks down black and white hallways while listening to garbled audio tracks like Charles Manson interviews and Hitler’s speeches. Occasionally, an image will pop up blocking your way, often depicting murders. The only other characters are terrifying little children that don’t interact with you at all – until the end, where one kills you.

Here’s the really fun bit: no one’s sure who made this, where it came from, or what the goal is.

But there’s nothing the internet likes more than a mystery, so speculation and research into just WTF this thing was exploded last year. If you want to go down the rabbit hole, this dedicated subreddit has plenty to keep you busy for a few days. We can say with confidence that this is one of those dark video games you’ll want to play with the lights on.

 

9. Danganronpa

Never heard of this game? I’m excited for you right now. Because you’re about to go on a wild ride reading this completely accurate description of the premise:

A sadistic teddy bear locks you in a school with 14 other students, one of whom you must murder without getting caught. Only if you pull this off may you leave the school – but when you do, the teddy bear executes all the remaining kids. Or you can get it wrong and you’ll also die. So basically, you die or you die, and you die by homicidal psycho teddy bear.

Need we say more?

 

10. Spec Ops: The Line

Most modern warfare FPS titles are more focused on delivering solid online multiplayer thrills with the single player campaigns serving more as a vanilla obligation than the highlight of the experience. They can’t help it – they’re just following trends in the gaming community. So it should go without saying that Spec Ops should be the same, right?

Not even close. The campaign’s story and stomaching what your character must do is emotionally difficult to handle. Instead of glorifying combat, Spec Ops makes you realize just how disastrous it really is for everyone involved – which, by the end of the game, will include you.

 

Our list was pretty comprehensive, but obviously we didn’t include them all. What dark video games do you know and love? Or which ones scarred you so badly you can’t help but tell others to avoid it? Add your darkest games in the comments section – can you top ours?

title.rendered: Indie Game of the Week: Keep Talking And Nobody Explodes

content.rendered:
I’ve defused many ’a’ bombs throughout my gaming history but never have I felt like I was Jeremy Renner in The Hurt Locker. Thanks to Samsung and the fine folks at Steel Crate Games, I can finally check that off the bucket list. That’s right – I’m referring to the hit indie game “Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes”.

My bucket list is cooler than your bucket list.

Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes is easily the most slap-happy defusal experience ever. It’s not only an amazing party game but one of the most hilarious applications of VR to date (not that you have to play it in virtual reality, but it helps up the ante), Keep Talking debuted on the Gear VR back in July of 2015 with staggered releases on Windows (Rift and Vive optional), Mac OS, and, most recently, the Playstation VR.

Steel Crate Games is the brilliant studio behind Keep Talking, unleashing what started as an entry in the Global Game Jam of 2014 unto the world, Ottawa based developers Ben, Allen and Brian joined forces and made the first version of the game in 48 hours to immediate critical acclaim. Based on the overwhelmingly positive reception, they formed the company to flush out their first project.

*channels inner Jeremy Renner*

The beauty of the game, regardless of  whether or not it’s played in VR, is the co-op nature with which you must tackle the bomb. Player 1 is the defuser, responsible for examining the bomb and actually pulling the right wires to render it harmless. Player 2 reads from the manual, providing the necessary information for the bomb handler to succeed. While it sounds simple, there seems to be an infinite number of obstacles to go along with the convoluted directions Player 2 must decipher just to give Player 1 a chance; and oh yeah – there’s an incessant alarm that rings true right when you get in the groove of things which the player is responsible for turning off…or not.

Uhh…maybe I’m not qualified for this…

I can’t imagine having to listen to more than one person attempt to direct me through the defusal. It’s mind-boggling enough just trying to keep sense of what one set of directions are with all their stipulations (if the wire is blue and the detonator says boom, stand up and rub your belly)! Having to listen to more than one voice compete for control of the manual would instantly give anyone synesthesia.

We first played Keep Talking in the office back when the HTC Vive was released. We had a blast playing and it was just happenstance that I recently purchased a Samsung product that came with the Gear VR. Great timing! You can imagine how exciting it was to see a familiar title in this new headset of mine. This is where The Hurt Locker comes in; I am the defuser now.

Channeling complete. Ladies, please restrain yourselves.

You can pick up Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes pretty much everywhere, but start here. Go on – unleash the Jeremy Renner within you!

title.rendered: VR vs AR — What’s the Future of Horror Gaming?

content.rendered:
A war is being fought for your soul. Or rather, being fought for the right to terrify your soul. That’s right – it’s a battle royale: VR vs AR.

No matter the size of the dispute, this is how everything is settled.

It’s certainly been a long, arduous year. 2016 will be remembered for killing too many pop stars/celebrities & for giving us one of the ugliest elections the US has ever seen. It also brought VR vs AR to the forefront, with Pokemon Go being a thing and companies finally bringing virtual reality to the masses. With a slew of options hitting the market concurrently, most notably Oculus Rift, Samsung Gear, and HTC Vive, consumers finally have affordable options for experiencing next-level immersion gaming like never before. And while sales haven’t met the market’s expectations out the gate, VR is still expected to be a $21 billion industry by 2020.

Whether game developers would prefer to sit out this new era is irrelevant – a pile of money that huge demands attention from the industry. And some of the most interesting early action is coming from the folks who make a living by crafting nightmares. This bodes well for consumers, because we oddly seem to enjoy living them through our device screens.

It seems most companies in the VR vs AR debate have sided with the former, if only because the technology is easier for customers to understand. On paper, horror gaming and virtual reality is a match made in heaven. The genre makes a living on Psychology and getting inside a player’s head. While all games can achieve new levels of immersion with VR, perhaps no other category lives and dies by its ability to put a gamer ‘in the room’, truly feeling the emotions their avatar must be experiencing.

But this is already old news. Most of the viral VR demos in the past year have been horror games. The reason is obvious: a cute girl wearing a Vive saying ‘Ooooh’ while playing virtual golf is twenty thousand times less entertaining than the same girl screaming ‘AHHHHH MOTHER F*CKER!!!’ when a demon charges her in an abandoned basement.

These days, the scares have graduated above demos. The biggest horror franchise to embrace VR is Resident Evil, Capcom’s eternal cash cow. Say what you want about the movies, but those films have grossed $900 million internationally, and the series has sold upwards of 69 million games since 1996. If a major developer staking their largest franchise on virtual reality doesn’t convince you VR is here to stay, nothing will.

“VR is a perfect match for a horror game,” says Jun Takeuchi, a corporate developer for Resident Evil 7. “A player screaming out in terror is the sweetest music to our ears.”

Unfortunately, early testers of RE7 have done less screaming and more vomiting. Reviews have been aggressively negative of Capcom’s ability to keep players from losing their lunch, especially following a July gaming Expo. Kotaku won the headline wars: “Resident Evil 7 in VR is a Nauseating Mess.”

The game doesn’t release until 2017, theoretically giving Takeuchi and Co. plenty of time to iron out the bugs. The question is, will they be able to?

VR sickness isn’t a problem unique to RE7, even if it sounds like Capcom requires more puke buckets than most. Despite the hype train’s claims of total immersion, a combination of factors regularly makes VR players feel ill during games. The motion you ‘see’ in a headset versus what your brain expects to see when you’re ‘running’ is the usual suspect. Developers haven’t yet conquered the obstacle of a first-person avatar running full sprint while looking hard right. And besides, how immersive is Rift if everything looks fantastic, but you cognitively understand you’re sitting on a dirty futon in your dorm room the entire time?

God, what a dump.

That last bit is why not everyone’s buying VR as the end-all-be-all of horror gaming. VR vs AR is warming up for the long haul.

You’re already familiar with augmented reality, even if you haven’t heard the term. A certain mobile game that shall go unnamed – it rhymes with Shmokemon Joe – features digital characters overlaid into the real world. Players explore actual places in the real universe that are simply enhanced by digital technology. That formula became a worldwide phenomenon, earning $200 million in a single month and spawning several porn spin-offs. All of this accomplished with AR.

VOID, or Vision of Infinite Dimensions, wants to build on that concept. The press release describes the platform as, “leading the world in a new form of immersive entertainment. A combination of a physical set, real-time interactive effects and virtual reality are utilized to create powerful HYPR REALITY experiences that meld digital and physical worlds together.”

But that’s just a lot of fancy marketing words, when really, if you watch this video, the only description you need is ‘amazeballs’:

Did you watch it? Good. You see what they’ve done. ‘Immersion’ can be a difficult concept for a game, horror or otherwise, to achieve while your sitting on your dad’s La-Z-Boy. Instead, these evil geniuses give you a simple real-world environment to run around in, and overlay it with digital assets. What’s more, all this actual human movement reportedly eliminates much of the VR nausea RE7 is now notorious for.

Now, imagine you turn a blind corner in a game, and the chick from ‘The Ring’ is staring you down. At home wearing a Vive, you shout, maybe jump in your seat left a few inches, then slam the joysticks backwards as fast as possible. In the future as conceived by VOID, you’ll legitimately have to sprint backwards while dodging poisonous mist fired from real jets hidden in the walls.

Which sounds more immersive to you?

Either way, you’ll probably need adult diapers.

None of this is to say one platform will clearly dominate the horror gaming market of the future. VOID’s concept isn’t yet open to the public – they’re hoping to open just a few locations in early 2017. Home VR has obvious accessibility advantages. But when it comes to an ‘experience’, it’s hard to argue with that AR promo video.

So who won the VR vs AR war? Will the conflict ever end? What will resolve this battle?

Perhaps then, the split will look something like the equilibrium struck by paintball and Call of Duty. One is undoubtedly the more thrilling activity, the closest simulation to real gun fighting short of actual combat.

But you can’t stumble home half-drunk from a bar at 1:00 AM and go paint-balling.

Paintball tanks are okay at any hour, however.

title.rendered: Indie Game of the Week: Deathstate

content.rendered:
If you haven’t already survived the rouguelike, bullet hell, single-stick astral projection that is Deathstate; you really should consider doing so immediately. Without getting into the reasons behind why so many great indie titles get slept on, I think it’s important to focus on the reasons that incentivize a purchase. Deathstate is one of those titles that makes it easy to find reasons to buy. It’s a solid, all-around fun game to play, and one that you’ll have a hard time putting down (if you can survive, that is).

Case in Point – Forest of Torment. Unique selling point, spacious, 10/10 would vacation there again.

Deathstate started as a jam in-house at Workinman Interactive in 2013. Workinman is a web and mobile app company based in our home state of New York. After two years of polish post game-jam, Workinman released Deathstate to rave reviews in 2015. Even though Workinman was founded in 2006, Deathstate is the studio’s first major independent release.

It’s one of those games that’s easy to pick up yet difficult game to master. The learning curve is such that if you don’t utilize the right balance of weapons, items and spells within half an hour of starting, you probably won’t survive another 15 minutes. Your character is drawn to the biggest enemy on screen, all the while being surrounded by ghouls, goblins, and ghosts in horrifyingly huge numbers. The challenge, and subsequent torment, are ingratiating nonetheless.

Cthulhu is indeed running for president. A vote for Cthulhu is a vote for evil! Vote today!

It’s small elements like this that help add to the sensation of speed that comes with Deathstate. The combination of gameplay from fan favorites like Castlevania and Binding are brought together with an art and sound direction that really create a unique experience. And did I mention that the team behind Deathstate are fans of all things 80’s lovecraftian horror? That’s so rad, right?

Speaking of the team – meet Peter:

Nice game you got there, Pete!

I first met Peter Lazarski at PAX East 2016. Peter is the co-creator of Deathstate as well as its art director. I could tell right away that he was the type of guy who loved Halloween (who doesn’t?). It was a combination of the retro lights blasting from the Deathstate demo and the way he led me to their booth with the power of his personality from 100 yards away. In addition to his role at Workinman, he also makes comics and games as Imaginary Monsters. He’s making his own titles using Gamemaker. So he’s pretty much an all-around awesome dude making awesome games. Nice.

Just in time for the festivities of October 31st, you should check out his latest retro 8-bit platformer, Halloween Forever. In this jovial gem, you play as a creepy animated pumpkin trying to figure out why creepy things are happening…creepily. Also you vomit candy corn, so there’s that. Which is awesome. But most importantly, it teaches us the true meaning of Halloween, which is to jump from platform to platform to tackle spooky scary skeletons challenges head on. Doesn’t that just warm you right up? Keep Halloween in your hearts always.

THIS IS HALLOWEEN! THIS IS HALLOWEEN!

Pick up this great indie gem on Steam for $15. Trust me it’s worth it. And you could’ve had it for 50% off if you weren’t sleeping. And if you’re just plain cheap you should try Halloween Forever for $2.99. Grab both – you’ll regret it otherwise!

title.rendered: Embracing Final Fantasy X: An Argument For Linear RPGs

content.rendered:
Poor Square-Enix – they just can’t seem to please everyone with their most famous franchise.

…and when they’re not busy disappointing fans, they’re busy confusing the world of high fashion.

Final Fantasy XV will soon be upon us, and although many fans eagerly await the newest addition to the family, some have expressed doubt and disgust over certain aspects of the game. Complaints address things like no main female characters and the main method of transportation being a car – two wildly divergent facets to the long and storied Final Fantasy universe that have elicited negative responses at worst and curious responses at best.

Of course, that’s the beauty of Final Fantasy – each new iteration features a completely new storyline with different characters that adhere to different laws, customs, and belief systems. Some things are added, some things are removed, but Squeenix does a pretty good job of making every title similar enough to remain within the Final Fantasy Family.

But where there are differences, there are also similarities – Final Fantasy III and Final Fantasy X-2 shared a similar job system, all Final Fantasys have summonings (given different names each time, naturally), and of course Cid appears in every iteration.

Yes, that is Cid…ney. Cindy. Yes, we have the weirdest boner right now.

Perhaps the most consistent complaint that is echoed throughout the entirety of the internet, however, is that Final Fantasy games are becoming increasingly more restricted. Freedom finds itself limited as players are often unable to utilize an overworld map. Another qualm comes from the lack of an airship early in the game, limiting travel to a straight line. When freedom is diminished, exploration grinds to a halt. All at once, the gamers cry “this game is far too linear”!

This was never more apparent than when Final Fantasy X was released. In the tenth installment, players assume the role of Tidus, a young Blitzball player from Zanarkand, who has washed ashore on the strange island of Besaid. Since he has nowhere to go, he decides to join a novice summoner named Yuna on her religious pilgrimage. Their journey takes them from one end of Spira to the other as they collect powerful aeons to destroy the great evil known as Sin. As this is a pilgrimage, players are restricted from jumping around the continent all willy-nilly and must adhere to the plan that has been laid out for them. Since there’s no immediate access to an airship and all traversing is done on foot, this absolute straight-line sojourning makes the game the very definition of a linear RPG.

This didn’t sit well with many players, who had, only a few years prior, played the extremely free-roaming Final Fantasy VII – many of whom cannot find much, if any, fault with.

So…if Final Fantasy VII, the airship-loving, overworld-map-having fan favorite, is the supposed gold standard of Final Fantasy games, what saving grace does Final Fantasy X and other linear RPGs like it have?

Could it be…

Nah, just kidding.

The answer lies in its problem: linearity, its greatest weakness, is also its greatest strength.

Remember that chilling Joker quote from The Dark Knight?

“Nobody panics when things go “according to plan.” Even if the plan is horrifying! If, tomorrow, I tell the press that, like, a gang banger will get shot, or a truckload of soldiers will be blown up, nobody panics, because it’s all “part of the plan”. Introduce a little anarchy. Upset the established order, and everything becomes chaos.”

Although the Joker was a fictional psychopath, he was a fictional psychopath with truth in his words. People make plans. They execute those plans. They follow those plans. And if something happens to cause a slight deviation, they try to get back to following the plans. In those moments where they’ve lost their way, there’s potential for confusion, anxiety, and hopelessness. Why? Because things didn’t go according to plan.

“Where’s my explosions? Goddamnit, what clown put this together?”

Final Fantasy X carefully laid out a very structured plan from the beginning – Yuna’s pilgrimage literally took her in a straight line, and players knew exactly which temples to visit and where to go next. After a brief indoctrination, they learned why she was on this important and sacred journey. Everyone understood that this plan, no matter how difficult or how inconsequential it seemed, must be fully executed. This was the entire purpose of this game.

So it was a devastating blow when the truth behind Yuna’s pilgrimage was slowly but surely revealed to be not only fatal, but inherently flawed. Eventually, the plan, once unquestioningly followed by summoner after summoner, found itself discarded. The group became depressed and in despair but remained determined to defeat Sin at any cost. In the end, they took on the true evil behind Sin. They did this without a plan, somehow bringing peace to all of Spira.

…until the shitty girl power sequel that practically undid everything the first title explained, that is.

When I first played this game, I fell into the trap it had laid out for players. I wanted things to go to plan. I wanted to move fluidly from one town to the next. But when that plan fell to pieces, I didn’t know what to expect. I yearned for the plan and bemoaned any unnecessary deviations from the charted course. I just wanted what was once considered safe and comfortable back again. It didn’t matter if there were terrible consequences; at least I could predict what would happen. A plan was safe; the unknown was not.

And it was in that moment of anxiety that I realized how much I valued the linear gameplay. It dawned on me how it had enhanced the overall storyline. I wasn’t travelling to a random location because <insert reason here>; rather, I had a logical progression ahead of me. What logical progression, you may ask? Why, the logical progression drilled into my head for the previous 20 hours. Instead of moving from one arbitrary location to the next, towns completely interchangeable with each other, I clung fervently to the straight and narrow even though life as Tidus&Co. knew it was desperately trying to throw them off the trail.

This doesn’t mean that all games that feature absolute freedom have terrible storylines, but it does make for a different experience. After playing several years of Skyrim, the storyline has become far too muddled for me to remember everything all my characters have done. I mostly just remember actively avoiding the main questline entirely. I thoroughly enjoy Skyrim, but I don’t play it for the story at all. This truth goes for all the sandbox RPGs in my library. And while many of those games with seemingly unlimited freedoms are fun, the stories are largely forgettable.

See, I only vaguely remember this part of Skyrim. Something to do with Helgen?

Final Fantasy X, on the other hand, is incredibly unique in its story – thanks to its linear gameplay. And while completely linear gameplay can often be boring, Final Fantasy X used that to its advantage. It knew when to dispense with it, introducing almost complete anarchy at the very last moment and making players yearn for the linear familiarity.

Will Final Fantasy XV draw from the freedom-loving Final Fantasy VII and its similar siblings? Or will it buck the trend and adopt the linear gameplay Final Fantasy X utilized so perfectly? Only time will tell. Linear or not, Final Fantasy XV remains hotly anticipated. Certainly, no matter what its gameplay is like, we’re in for the standard treat that is a Final Fantasy title.
