title.rendered: RuneScape is Still a Thing?

content.rendered:
I was the coolest f*cking middle-schooler. I wore a pooka shell necklace. I owned a very respectable collection of Beanie Babies, as well as Blink 182’s Enema of the State. My shoes could deploy wheels from their heels on command, letting me roll around the school hallways like the voice-cracking pimply-faced badass I was. And almost every night after my parents fell asleep, I would sneak downstairs, turn on the family’s extremely terrible Dell computer, log on the shitty DSL, and play old-school Runescape for hours.

Gotta reminisce fast!

I’m more than aware this wasn’t something the cool kids bragged about back then, but in hindsight, a positively massive number of teenagers and adults alike spent unprecedented number of hours grinding away in (arguably) the first great fantasy MMORPG. Because in those early days – Runescape was first released in 2001 – there was no match to the open-world adventure Jagex provided via browser.

We uh..remember it looking better in our memories…

But as technology advanced, scores of other online fantasy games have come and, in many cases, gone. World of Warcraft, EverQuest, Guild Wars, Tera, Elder Scrolls – the list could probably fill a mid-sized suburban library. And with the advent of these advanced, gorgeous, immersive and wildly popular adventure titles, the gaming world moved on from little old Runescape.

Or did it?

15 years after its release, Runescape just landed at number 9 on the list of 2016’s Most Played MMORPGs worldwide. What’s more, it’s recognized by the Guinness Book of World Records as the ‘World’s Largest Free MMORPG’, as well as the most-updated.

Making Runescape an alumni with this guy…

That’s right. Even if you have moved on to bigger and better things, Runescape is still a juggernaut in online gaming, trucking along with an average of 50,000+ players logged on at any given time. And this for a game that’s only marginally evolved over the past decade and a half.

Perhaps that’s not fair. As mentioned, Runescape holds the world title for being the most updated MMO. This feat doesn’t even seem like it should be trackable. But take a quick scroll through the website’s News and Forum pages and you’ll see that Jagex is constantly dumping in more and more for its players to build, explore, and conquer.

Yet the basic tenants remain. The game’s most constant criticism is ‘the grind’ – you’re essentially leveling up skills by clicking trees and stoves and dragons on repeat. And while that’s true of most MMOs, there are few games out there that support the huge number of disparate skills available in Runescape. How many other games boast such boring yet necessary abilities as woodcutting, cooking, and mining?

Time well spent.

Then there’s gameplay and interface. Point-and-click is a genre with uncountable diehard fans, but these days, when you’re exploring digital worlds, you’re typically treated to silky smooth graphics and beautifully rendered landscapes. Runescape has released major overhauls of their graphic engine, most notably in 2007 and 2013. Unfortunately, it’s still extremely shit, especially next to what gamers are used to in 2016. And I mean that in the most loving way possible.

 

You see what I’m getting at. I can’t imagine being 13-years old today, with my eyeballs used to the high-octane action of Call of Duty and the porn-worthy graphics of Final Fantasy, and deciding that I’d rather spend hours leveling up an F2P character by starting pointless fires in a childishly rendered environment. So then, how do you explain Runescape’s continued popularity?

Anyone who’s played an MMO is aware of the tragically addicting nature of the games. Open-ended virtual worlds provide almost endless possibilities for progress. It doesn’t matter if acknowledge you’re ignoring leveling up in ‘real life’. The sense of achievement when you unlock that next level after hours of grinding is undeniable. Thus, successful MMOs have more staying power than linear games.

This is especially true once you’ve already sunk a huge number of hours into a title, which makes the nostalgia factor more than a sentimental connection – it’s a very real driver of staying power. Unlike FPS or linear adventure games, you’re less likely to bounce between half a dozen MMOs at once because you want to dedicate your gaming hours to upgrading one character as huge as possible. And as the first great fantasy MMO, Runescape was the market’s first mover, grabbing gamers well before the days of WoW and the rest. And ever since, even if you’ve personally moved on, Jagex’s constant updates guarantee the die-hards always have something new to do.

Awesome, now onto vacuuming and goat herding grinding!

But at the foundation of both these points is what made Runescape popular back in the day. To this day, it maintains what others cannot: accessibility.

Sure, there are other free-to-play MMORPGs that anyone can explore with minimal effort and financial commitment. But aside from simply being first, Runescape’s browser play makes it available to a group of would-be heroes many first world gamers forget about. Not everyone’s running state of the art graphic cards or surfing with ultra-high speed fiber-optic connections. Not everyone’s turned off by simpler art designs. As long as it runs smoothly, it still satisfies that bone-deep need for adventure.

At age 13, I spent hours sitting in my family’s basement with the lights out on an already obsolete Dell. Armed with the most craptastic of internet connections, I could run Runescape perfectly fine. I didn’t have to download anything my parents would be mad about. I didn’t have to ask for a credit card. Shit, I didn’t even have to admit I was playing an MMORPG. And for these reasons, it was my first gaming love. It hooked me for far more many years than I’d care to admit.

Plus Runescape taught us all how to type and you’re lying if you say otherwise.

The internet is universally faster these days. Spending a frankly obscene number of hours leveling up an avatar is much more societally acceptable than it once was. But for a segment of younger, teenage players, I’d wager Runescape’s unprecedented accessibility is still a massive turn on. And even if they don’t discover for themselves, they have my generation to point them in the right direction.

title.rendered: Indie Game of the Day: Distance

content.rendered:
It’s hard to set yourself apart in the indie scene, and that rings true specifically in the racing genre. With limited time, money, and other resources, many racing games end up looking the same and share the same amount of disappointments…except when it comes to Refract Studio’s newest title, Distance.

Refract Studios is composed of a core group of developers who collaborated on projects during their time at the Digipen Institute of Technology. Founded in 2012, they worked on Solace, The Fourth Wall and Nitronic Rush. Refract’s debut title, Distance, is the spiritual successor to Nitronic Rush and is currently available on Steam’s early access.

Distance successfully raised not quite $162,000 on Kickstarter back at the end of 2012. Refract has been thorough in their development. A Greenlight campaign as well as a planned alpha and beta proceeded the early access version that launched at the end of 2014. I had the chance to express my love of Distance to a studio member at PAX West 2016 – I guess you can say I have been eagerly awaiting this indie gem for some time.

What makes it different than other racing games?

The survival theme is typically reserved for the horror or action-adventure genre; however, Distance incorporates these mechanics seamlessly into fast-paced racing gameplay. In tandem with how enjoyably frustrating maneuvering through the gorgeous cityscape can be, there are enough lasers, buzzsaws and obstacles to make Distance a true survival racing game. There’s nothing worse than watching your car get bisected like a GoW Locust while an opponent speeds past on their way to victory.

It’s not just Jedi-like reflexes you need to survive in Distance; right when you think you’ve run out of road, wings sprout from your car and you lift off like a Musk on his way to Mars. Like what? Talk about unique! And the newness doesn’t end there – the visuals and feel are truly remarkable. This dark world is illuminated only by neon checkpoints and a Tron aesthetic. The linear art direction only adds to the sense of speed. Couple that with a Deadmau5-esque score at 180bpm and your heart will truly be pounding as you white-knuckle your controller. It’s truly the feel of the game that sets it apart from the rest.

I’ve always loved cars, as I grew up on a dealership lot, and I’ve always loved racing games. My first time was with Gran Turismo on the PlayStation. I enjoyed tinkering in Need for Speed Underground on the PS2. I grew to love the supercars in Project Gotham Racing 3 on the Xbox 360. With this genuine love and experience I have with this genre, I argue that it’s the survival nature of Distance that puts it in a league of its own. Countless gameplay modes make it enticing, be it competing online, on the couch with a friend or even by yourself trying to beat your best time.

Refract’s grand design ensures that Distance’s full release is packed to the roof with content. This is because the developers added a level editor for fans to generate new content; literally 1,700+ workshop levels and counting ensure that fans will be occupied until time immemorial.

Check out the game here and look for it on the PlayStation 4 sometime in 2016. Do you dare to go the Distance? You know you want to!

title.rendered: Why Your Brain Loves the Gears of War Song

content.rendered:
There’s a great line in the movie Concussion when Will Smith is challenging the NFL over their head injury policies: “You’re going to war with a corporation that owns a day of the week.”

No, not that day…

That’s only barely an exaggeration. Odds are, if you’re not glued to the TV every Sunday watching football while incessantly refreshing fantasy scores, you’ve dated someone who does. And you’re not alone — in 2015, single NFL games were 45 of the top 50 most watched shows on cable television, averaging nearly double the viewership of primetime network slots.

Advertisers know this, which is why NFL commercials cost the GDP of small nations. Last season, a thirty-second spot during a nationally televised game cost near-as-makes-no-difference $500,000, and primetime games on Sunday and Monday nights can run even higher.

I tell you all this so you appreciate how huge Gears of War 4 just went to air this 2-minute launch trailer smack in the middle of Monday Night Football:

Remember puberty? When your hormones finally kicked in, and all of a sudden you start having confusing, tingly feelings that you’d never experienced before? That’s how Gears of War trailers affect many people: you don’t fully understand why, but even though you’re watching OTT grotesque monster gore, you have the #feels.

Now, before dissenters angrily type long-winded comments, obviously no commercial is universally popular. You don’t have to like this trailer; maybe this isn’t your cup of Earl Grey. But the fact is, Gears of War is Xbox’s second-most successful franchise, only behind Halo in total sales. And you don’t put up those kind of numbers unless your marketing team is doing something right.

The formula isn’t new. The ad men struck gold with the first Gears of War trailer back in 2006, and haven’t tweaked the recipe since. This ought to look familiar:

That trailer still remains one of the most adored video game ads in history. And if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it – every title in the Gears of War series features the same formula: human soldiers on growth hormones; depressing post-apocalyptic environment; terrifying monsters and high-octane thrills. And all of that bonkers action set to a slow emotional song.

You’re a smart person. You can deduce why these trailers make an impression. They catch you off guard by showing you exploding heads and chainsaw bayonets, which is attention grabbing in its own right. But then, instead of back dropping that warfare with Slayer or Rise Against, they play songs usually only found on the playlists of emo teenagers.

And according to Gears of War sales over the past decade, it works. But why?

Per usual, science can provide the answers. We’re not enthralled with these advertisements by coincidence – the boys on Madison Avenue are using tried and true psychological ploys to lock these trailers in your mind.

First and most basically, these ads are different. Watch enough TV, and you become at least subconsciously aware of the standard formula used in every commercial. A happens then B happens then C happens, lots of pretty people smile, they flash a crowd-tested logo at the end and play some upbeat music in the background.

 

When an ad breaks that mold, your brain reacts. And it’s usually for the better.

We humans are creatures of habit, so when something new and unexpected happens, it catches us a bit off guard. This is especially true in television. If we’re vegging out in front of our flat screen, most of us are doing as little thinking as possible. No, really – our brains literally shutdown while we’re in front of the TV. When something abnormal appears that you’re not ready or willing to process, your brain’s first reaction is ‘what is this?’ and your curiosity is piqued.

The technical term for this phenomenon is ‘habituation’ – essentially, we love routines, but routines get old so we like something new every so often. Subconsciously, we want the same things over and over again, but after a while we need a shake-up to keep things interesting. Of course, going “full-tilt interesting” can certianly backfire – that’s why most advertisers stick to the tried and true and boring. To make anything else is risky, both for the product and their careers.

So throwing a change-up at the masses’ psyche can go horribly wrong. When it goes right – like it did for Gears or War – it’s a homerun. Still though, what makes this ‘go right’?

There’s an element of cognitive dissonance at play. You’re drawn to the fact that the trailer’s visuals don’t match the audio. It doesn’t make sense, and thus your brain’s having a fundamentally foreign reaction (per habituation) to what it’s processing. But that exact reaction is what’s making it memorable.

Then there are the emotional aspects of the music. The ad shows intense, cold-blooded sci-fi warfare – quite possibly the least romantic scenes imaginable. Yet instead of playing up those gory aspects with hard rock or metal tracks, the trailer adds emotional layers by dropping in a tune that you’d only expect to hear during a Saturday night pity party of one.

Oh no, Dawson, please don’t cry…

This manipulation, in fact, is a major gripe with many video game reviewers. Because of the unique musical choices, the trailers lead us to believe the game will feature heavy character development and complex emotional storylines. Gears of War titles do have a bit of this, but not nearly to the degree the advertisements would have you believe.

But that was never the point. The commercial’s audio tracks weren’t picked as a nod to aspects of the gameplay, they were simply chosen as a clever scheme to sell product. A surprising commercial that throws off a viewer’s subconscious, but makes up for and takes advantage of your brain’s attention by being emotionally manipulative and undeniably cool? Slapped right in the middle of Monday Night Football?

If you didn’t read this in his voice, you’re too young for you, bruh.

Here, take our money.

title.rendered: Pokenomics: PoGo PLUS vs. Supply And Demand

content.rendered:
Pokemon Go offered perhaps the most fun lesson in Supply and Demand that I’ve ever had.

On June 23rd, I preordered my Pokemon Go PLUS accessory. On September 20th, I finally received it (a 90 day wait, but who’s counting?).

I also received offers for free Pokecoins and I cannot for the life of me figure out what the benefit is for these accounts.

My cost was $35.00 plus tax and shipping, which amounted to about $44.00. This was waaaaaay more than I wanted to spend on an accessory for a mobile app game (which is typically $0.00), but I figured that was still not very much money for a self-proclaimed Pokefanatic. Besides, it’d be a great story to tell my kids or something. Whatever crappy excuse I could think of to rationalize my purchase aside, I clicked preorder and played the waiting game for three long months (which is, incidentally, 2 1/2 months longer than I played Pokemon Go).

I’ll admit I was pleased when GameStop emailed me earlier this month to let me know that my Pokemon Go PLUS was on its way, but that feeling was immediately overcome with shock when, a few short days later, my coworkers were sporting the device that hadn’t yet appeared in my mailbox. Curious, I asked how they were able to receive theirs quicker than I had. Was there a mistake in the address? Was my shipment lost? Did someone get their hands on it before I could?

If Pokemon has taught me anything, it’s that these guys are behind the case of the missing Pokemon Go PLUS!

It turns out no foul play was afoot, but that my coworker had simply gone to Frank & Son’s, a local warehouse filled with booths peddling nerdy wares year-round, to purchase the device. He considered it a steal at $70, informing me that most places were selling it for $100 or more.

Yikes. He wasn’t kidding.

This struck me as very odd – naturally, I wanted the device as much as the next trainer, but I wasn’t about to spend more than retail value on it. On top of that, it got me thinking that maybe I could turn around and sell my device as well; since I have an android, the device barely works on my phone anyway, so why not recoup my losses and make a few quick bucks off it at the same time?

And it was at that moment that I realized the beautiful lesson Pokemon Go PLUS was teaching us about one of the basic rules of economics: supply and demand.

Supply is defined as the amount of any given product that exists, and demand is defined as how much of the product that people want. In this scenario, the product is the Pokemon Go PLUS, the supply is how much of the device exists, and the demand is, well, evident – people want it, and they want it ASAFP.

While it’s unclear how many Pokemon Go PLUS devices were made, it’s easy to see that the number was woefully inadequate. Preorders sold out within the first few weeks, and at launch, the physical stores sold their stock in an instant. With no more devices in immediate production, savvy re-sellers knew this would be an opportunity to make some cash. They bought up the devices at $35.00 and resold them at a higher cost, often doubling or tripling their profits.

This image was titled “free pokecoins wee” and we thought you all should know that.

Instead of turning up their noses at the exorbitant cost, some trainers have been snapping up the devices regardless of the increased pricetag, The price is key to understanding the relationship between supply and demand. If supply is low and demand is high, this law dictates that price will go up. The scarcity of the object coupled with its desirability gives it an inflated perceived value, and people will still be willing to pay above retail price if they want it badly enough.

The law of supply and demand dictates that the inverse is also true – if the demand is low but the supply is high, the price will inevitably go down. This is probably what Niantic feared when they went to production with the Pokemon Go PLUS; instead of confidently making a lot of devices, they made a small amount to “test the waters”, so to speak. Should the product have been a total flop, the large quantity of unsold PLUS devices would sit around in warehouses collecting dust. They’d liquidate at a reduced price and lose money in the long run.

By making a limited amount of gadgets, Niantic was able to safely make some money. Judging by the reaction to the device, they certainly could have made more to increase profits. They must have believed that the risk was not worth taking, no matter how big the potential reward could be. This limited supply with the added intense demand drove the price unreasonably high. The value is currently set at whatever a trainer is willing to pay for it; at the moment, that appears to be around $100.

Damn, it feels good to be a gangsta.

If Pokemon Go has taught us anything, it’s that a week or two will pass and the Pokemon Go PLUS craze, much like the game itself, will fade. Resellers that haven’t sold their gadgets at the increased price will have to make a hard choice. Either stubbornly stick to three figures or will lower it down to something more reasonable. The latter would probably be enough to make a profit, certainly, but not the crazy gains they’d hoped for. This is because demand for the product has decreased, despite the supply remaining a constant. Simple supply and demand, right?

Good news for those trainers that have yet to get their hands on a device. Bad news for those that spent the beau-coup bucks on the Pokemon Go PLUS.

title.rendered: Ghost In The Shell Movie’s Whitewashing: Why It’s Bad & How Video Games Can Teach Hollywood A Lesson

content.rendered:
By now, everyone knows about the new Ghost in the Shell movie. Last night, five short trailers released, teasing fans with ten second glimpses of what’s to come. And unless you’ve lived under a rock for the past few months, you’ve surely seen the controversial news surrounding this movie. By casting Scarlett Johannson, the Ghost in the Shell movie, true to Hollywood form, has Whitewashed yet another Asian character.

An exclusive look behind the scenes of the Ghost in the Shell movie!

Wait before you write me off as some whiny female SJW with an arbitrary axe to grind. I promise I’m not that at all. Truthfully, I don’t care about Tracer poses or female nudity in video games or whathaveyou. Actually, I think it’s great that video games offer the fantastical freedom that film cannot express. I’ve put in dozens of hours in HuniePop in order to attain 100% completion. After playing it, I even wrote about how awesome it is. I immediately volunteered to do the Nutaku writeup for EquityArcade. Simultaneously, I don’t mind putting in a good Pokemon porn article (…for Science).

I say all this to impart how different this article is from the standard white noise (no pun intended). I’d like readers to have the careful thought that it deserves. It’s a legitimate issue that Asian-Americans face today. 

But instead of a White girl with good intentions trying to explain a problem that indirectly affects me (Korean-American husband yo), I decided to go straight to the source. I interviewed two Asian-American actors well-versed in these issues; Kelvin Han Yee, a veteran in the Asian-American acting community (both on stage and on screen) and Courtney Kurata, an actress still trying to find her way in the industry.

When asked what Whitewashing meant to them, they responded similarly. “The term ‘whitewashing’ to me means taking something from an ethnic background or non-Western culture, and taking and changing it to please and appeal to the general Western or White masses”, said Kurata. Yee agreed, noting that there is a distinction between Whitewashing and Yellowface. Yellowface is the practice of putting on makeup to change the appearance of a White person to be Asian. Both, he says, are harmful and should discontinue.

When asked how it affected their careers, they again spoke similarly about their limitations they faced due to their race. “I have not had the opportunities that my White peers have had to develop themselves as artists. I began in theater. My White peers would set goals like ‘I’m gonna be Romeo or Hamlet before I’m 30’. And those goals were achievable for them. At this stage in my career, I should be playing weighty parts like “The Scottish King”. I should have that available to me, but it’s not.

I’ll tell you a story to illustrate the obstacles I’ve had to overcome. I was the first Asian American actor in the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in Ashland in its 65 years of history. When we performed that year, the organization received letters; people were disappointed because they ‘planned this trip all year’ only to see an Asian man on stage. They complained it was ‘not meant to be performed that way’. It had nothing to do with my performance – it was my race that they took issue with. And that’s hard to deal with, because that can affect decisions made by casting directors; with the recent Dr. Strange casting of ‘the Ancient One’…I mean, that could have been me. I could have auditioned for that, but it wasn’t made open to Asian men. My career is often stunted due to Whitewashing like that, and it’s hard.”

Above: A 500+ year old Asian man with magical powers who ages very, veeeeery slowly.

Kurata agreed. “When it comes to my career as an actor, it’s been rather difficult auditioning. This is especially true for specific Asian roles. Hollywood and the entertainment industry still wants to box Asian people into a stereotype. As a tall, curvy, Japanese American woman, I go into these auditions facing racial judgement and comments. I’ve been told I’m too tall (I’m 5’8) or big to be Asian. I’ve been asked if I could read the lines in a silly Asian accent. Any post I come across for an Asian role says they’re looking for a female who can “play Asian (meaning not necessarily be Asian, but look similar), wear a size 0-4, be no taller than 5’4”, and have straight black/brown hair. Rarely do I ever see an Asian role as a lead. It’s usually for the part of a sidekick.

Growing up, I never really had an Asian actor to look up to. It made me wish I was White so I could be on TV or in a movie; then I would feel popular or significant in some way. I mean, the only Asian women I saw on screen were Tia Carrere, Ming Na, and Lucy Liu. But none of them looked like me or had anything I could relate to besides being Asian females. I think that’s why I’m still motivated to keep pursuing this dream. There’s such a lack of representation in Hollywood. Asians only represent about 1-2% of the industry, and we matter and have important stories to tell.”

Of course, there are those that argue Asians are not American. I’ve even heard it myself when I ask friends and family why they believe Asians aren’t in lead roles. They usually respond with “maybe their accents will be too hard to understand”. “They want an American, not an Asian”.

Kurata believes that is absolutely preposterous. “My grandparents were actually born in California, so they were United States citizens. Because of the bombing of Pearl Harbor, they were seen as the enemy. This was solely based on the way they looked and their surname. My grandparents met and got married in internment camp during WWII. They had to prove their allegiance and assimilate to Western society and culture for many many years afterwards. Even after all this, society barely accepted them. Growing up, my family has embraced more of the Western culture. But it does NOT mean we abandoned our heritage and culture. Sometimes it was a means to survive.”

Justin Bieber vs. Jay Park: which one is American and which one is the foreigner?

As you can see, the Ghost in the Shell movie and its Whitewashing has clear implications that affect actual people; simply put, White actors are “stealing” Asian American jobs. Jobs that Asians who are just as American as Scarlett Johannson or Emma Stone deserve. Realize that this wouldn’t be an issue if:

a) Roles that don’t require specific racial casting were opened up to any race (as Yee pointed out, Asians are often asked not to apply – even if the original character is Asian)
b) This lack of representation didn’t negatively impact the lives of actual people (as Kurata said, she once felt she wished to be White so she could “feel like she mattered”)
c) The current media representation of certain groups wasn’t practically completely negative (Asian men specifically are victims of misrepresentation, as they are often cast as emasculated, goofy immigrants when they are just as diverse as any other group of people)

Both Yee and Kurata had family that served the USA in WWII. They fought alongside fellow Americans that treated them as second-class citizens based upon their race alone. Today, we let this practice of alienation and discrimination continue. Whitewashing is one of these ways; appropriating the extremely few roles written for Asians by passing them out to Whites. Whites often do not *need* these roles; their stories are already consistently told in all forms of media.

But how does this and the Ghost in the Shell movie all tie into video games, anyway?

Surprisingly, this is where video games tend to differ – where Hollywood fails…ermm, Gamerwood? tends to succeed. Remember that fantastical freedom I mentioned earlier? Video game characters don’t need to occupy physical space and whatnot; there’s really no limitations on what they can look like. We see this more often with games that feature character customization; Elder Scrolls and Saints Row are some titles that let your character look like anything you’d like.

PC gamers take this a step further with mods and suddenly Spiderman is fighting Alduin Randy Savage. In my playthroughs of Saints Row IV, the President will always be a smoking hot buxom blonde. She’ll always wear nothing but pasties and a thong. Why? Because it’s hilarious to me that the POTUS can be practically naked. No one bats an eye or honks a boob; at least, until they get on the ship and…well, bat eyes and honk boobs. Awesome.

The best part about this photo is that it isn’t my POTUS but it looks pretty much just like her. Someone else agrees with me :).

This level of freedom allows players to choose what the main character looks like. This by itself is great, but there’s an incredible beauty to it. NPCs usually interact with them in the same manner despite their appearance. The same dialogue that a stereotypical leading male character would receive occurs even if my character looks completely different. She could be Stripperella or Rosie O’Donnell and she’ll garner the same respect. In that sense, games achieve true equality, strangely enough; NPCs treat the character as an individual and not as a race/gender combination. This means that video games have accomplished what Hollywood hasn’t. Remember to bring that gem up next time someone says video game character representation is sexist.

But what about games that don’t feature character customization? Are we stuck with playing the same type of stereotypical leading male character that plagues Hollywood?

Well…not always. Certainly there will be some overlap, but video games genres differ wildly from each other. Characters from video games based off movies or sports rely on the likenesses of their real life counterparts. On the other hand, genres like JRPGs, RTS, and FPS tend to feature diversity in the video game characters. Game developers, from indie to AAA, live all over the world; as such they make games that represent their worldview. This is often reflected in the characters they create. Japanese games are different than French games are different than American games; each country brings variety to their respective platforms, developing something for everyone.

While this doesn’t always improve the diversity of experience – i.e., the games may feature a diverse representation of gender/race combinations but the games themselves are still typically aimed at a specific (male-oriented) audience – it achieves what Hollywood usually does not. It achieves the representation of often marginalized groups of people that lend to an authentic, well-developed story. The diversity will never be perfect, but it’s certainly better than Hollywood’s standard M.O.

Sorry, we’re back; we missed a spot!

So what can Hollywood learn and apply to the Ghost in the Shell movie?

Hollywood can’t allow viewers to customize the main character to fit their wants/needs; they can, however, start branching out of this mindset they’ve seemingly created for themselves. Why the mindset that says audience members only want a White majority onscreen exists I do not know.

In truth, I believe we actually don’t care who we see on screen. We just want a good actor who can portray their character in a believable manner. This goes for the Ghost in the Shell movie as well. To cast someone like Scarlett Johannson as Motoko Kusanagi represents the loss of one layer of authenticity. Coupled with the issues regarding Whitewashing, I find all of this to be a crime; a crime against a story I consider almost sacred. This adaptation has me more disgusted than excited.

Ghost in the Shell is so quintessentially Japanese in a deep and contemplative way. As such, it has a hard time translating to non-Japanese adaptations. It was – and is – an amazing manga and incredible animated movie. But anything further than that and the original message of the story is muddled.

It requires the gentle touch of someone that understands what the manga was trying to convey. I daresay it’s near impossible. But if any one group of people would be able to accomplish this, it would be the Japanese nationals. After all, this is their story! As such, the Ghost in the Shell movie belongs to their capable directors, producers, and actors.

Live-action movies of animes are usually box-office bombs. Even Asian foreign films, like Old Boy and The Eye, usually tank. Going simply by the general trend, the Ghost in the Shell movie will too. It simply isn’t going to have the same profundity and complexity that the original had.

Part of the problem begins with Whitewashing; the inability for casting directors to see an Asian actor in an Asian role. Another part of the issue is a vague, partial understanding of the cultural conversation at the time. This is something that a Japanese person living in the ’90s would easily comprehend that Americans wouldn’t totally grasp.

Ghost in the Shell represents what might have been; a dystopian future based off Japanese fears, thoughts, emotions, and imaginations. Perhaps the message best belongs in their hands; untouched and unblemished by well-meaning yet culturally ignorant outsiders who cannot possibly recreate that level of greatness.

title.rendered: Civilization VI Wants to Evolve “Just Enough”

content.rendered:
Michael Jordan hadn’t won an NBA title. PlayStation was 3 years away. The USSR was still a thing, and Bill Clinton hadn’t yet been elected to the Oval Office, much less invented a new use for cigars.

wink wink nudge nudge know what I mean say no more

That was the world Sid Meier’s Civilization was born into, and for the past 25 years, millions of players have been building worlds of their own through diplomacy, strategy, and conquest.

The game is as simple as it is sprawling. Players take control of a civilization based on real-life dynasties; starting from prehistory, they develop their nation’s cities, armies, technology and more in a contest against other key leaders with the same goal: world domination.

That glorious DOS-based first iteration won more awards than Meryl Streep. It’s undeniably one of the most influential video games in history. In the past quarter-century, players have logged an estimated billion (yes, with a ‘b’) hours of gameplay on the dozen-plus iterations and expansion packs, courtesy of Micropose and Firaxis. This October, the sixth official version will hit the shelves. Millions of players should begin preparing for a voluntary vitamin D deficiency.

It’s really no wonder Civilization is one of the most played titles of all times. Each game is completely different — what with different maps and victory strategies and enemy configurations. There’s quite literally an infinite amount of possibilities in any one Civ title.

One thing, however, remains constant: Nuclear Gandhi

Which is interesting. Because if any one purchased Civ game offers a virtually unlimited play-hours-to-dollar ratio, what keeps the die-hard fans buying the new titles?

Few other video game series can claim such a long and storied run, but Mario and Zelda come to mind. Both have been around for decades, both have diehard fan bases, and both sell bajillions (yes, with a ‘b’) annually. But with a few exceptions, these are linear play-throughs that take an average player X amount of hours to complete. They don’t offer the infinite possibilities of Civ.

Popular online games haven’t been around as long but are perhaps more parallel. Case in point, WoW and Call of Duty. But even in these dynamic examples, you play in a world of the designer’s creation. And on top of that, what’s keeping the gameplay differentiated are the other human players; Civ is completely unpredictable even in single player. It’s almost as if there’s no need a multiplayer option.

(Fun and/or depressing side note: Sid Meier originally had no intention to incorporate multiplayer. He felt, “If you had friends, you wouldn’t need to play computer games.” Thanks Sid!)

Why you gotta hurt me like that, Sid?

So then, if someone could ostensibly play the same iteration of Civ forever, how has Sid & Co. sold 33 million copies (including expansions) over 25 years?

The topic came up at the DICE summit in Las Vegas. Game designers Bruce Shelley, Sid Meier, Brian Reynolds, and Soren Johnson were discussing Civ’s immortality. Their secret, in so many words, is evolving “just enough”.

Johnson elaborated, saying that in recent years they’d adopted a new policy. ”One-third old, one-third improved, and one-third new.” Meier himself agreed. “Some franchises go into overly large, overly complex ideas and crashed and burned.”

Mmhmm…

If you look at the series’ evolution, it’s easy to see how that strategy has been implemented. Outside the continual and dramatic cosmetic improvements, each iteration carries over the same basic gameplay tenants. Yet each one adds new elements that improve, or a the very least change, the experience for the hardcore fans. Civ 1 didn’t even have hit points; there were only two paths to victory in Civ 2. Culture didn’t exist until Civ 3 and Religion only became a major tool for 4. And after 19 successful years with millions of sales, Civ 5 introduced a completely revamped combat system. And those are only the flashiest adjustments to the major titles.

In this manner, Civ remains relevant but is poised as fresh and different. Every new Civ is current and exciting enough for new players, but familiar enough to the old warhorses. Which brings us to the million-dollar question: how is that strategy implemented for Civ 6?

The simultaneously boring-yet-exciting development is that Workers are finally gone, replaced with a more complicated ‘Builder’ unit. Then there’s cities – for the first time ever, your buildings and developments don’t all live on a single tile. Much of Civ 5’s combat features will carry over, with a few tweaks. But early play testers have widely commented on the improved, more dynamic diplomacy options.

“diplomacy”

And then there’s the vague yet seemingly major addition of ‘Active Progression’. According to lead designer Ed Beach, “It’s the idea that having your units and cities achieve successes helps your civ unlock technological secrets and build a strong society.” Meaning that, in the case of the Sailing and Navigation Technologies, you get boosts for having boats and cities on the coast, as opposed to completely landlocked civilizations. There’ll be similar bonus systems for all technologies; this Active Progression will likely affect many other facets of the game.

There’ll of course be more surprises waiting for players this October (rumors of a new victory condition abound). But looking at the formula for Civ 6 thus far, we can expect what’s worked for the past 25 years: evolving just enough.

Which is good. Because as designer Brian Reynolds put it, no one, “[…wants] to go down in history as the guy who broke Civilization.”

title.rendered: Friday the 13th: Can Developers Get It Right This Time?

content.rendered:
We have a strange love affair with Friday the 13th. It may have terrified us as children, but even then we watched it excitedly, despite the fact it was hard to see the screen through our fingers that reflexively covered our eyes. It’s this love affair that has kept the franchise alive through the decades, prompting cries for merchandise, remakes, and, of course, a Friday the 13th game. With each Halloween comes a renewed interest in one of the most infamous series of all time.

The origins of the superstitions surrounding Friday the 13th have been hotly debated, but we can at least pin down one very important year: 1980 – the first full feature film of Friday the 13th. In it and its progeny after it, camp counselors and campers alike were murdered in grotesque, various ways by a serial killer stalking around Camp Crystal Lake. In the first film, fans discovered that Pamela Voorhees, the mother of Jason Voorhees, is that killer. The protagonist, named Alice, beheads Pamela and flees to a canoe, the feeling of safety settling in as she calmly drifts to the center of the lake. Low and behold she isn’t safe; a horrific creature (later is revealed to be the undead Jason) emerges from said lake and drags her down to a watery grave.

I…don’t remember this part of the Titanic.

When fans saw this for the first time – Alice waking up in the middle of a serene lake with the comforting safety of police officers at the shore – they thought it was all over. With the killer(s), vanquished and Alice safe, viewers were ready to resume ironing their bell-bottoms for their upcoming disco contest or whatever else it was that they were doing in the late ’70s/early ’80s. Fans soon realized the false sense of security they felt, as Alice’s ear-shattering screech in response to Jason surging up from beneath the water to take her under made fans practically shit themselves with shock. Wasn’t the killer dead? How did Jason come back to life? Questions immediately piled up, and fans inhaled the sequels.

Sequels alone were not enough to satiate the ravenous hunger that fans had for the franchise; in 1989, Atlus and Pack-In-Video developed a Friday the 13th game for Nintendo (after seven freaking films, but take your time, whatever). LJN, notorious for publishing absolutely terrible titles, immediately picked up the rights to the Friday the 13th game in order to add it to their lackluster library. Because of course they did.

So was this one any different? Despite belonging to the LJN family, could the beloved franchise overpower the absolute garbage of its published brothers and sisters and set a shining example of a game based off a movie that, for once, isn’t absolutely godawful?

Turns out it sucks. It sucks real bad.

/sarcasm

So instead of getting the ultimate horror game we deserved (as ultimate as 8-Bit could be), we got a game that’s now known for residing on numerous “worst video games” lists. It even received the attention of YouTube personalities such as James Rolfe (the Angry Video Game Nerd) for its atrociously horrendous gameplay. Complaints are diverse yet similar in their disdain for the title – “too difficult”, “shoddy transition from movie to game”, and “repetitive music score and frustrating gameplay” were among the many scathing reviews it received in its lifetime.

1989 was quite a long time ago and the video game industry certainly grew up in the past quarter century; with that being said, games based off movies are still as terrible as ever, and horror games are no exception. Isn’t it about time that a classic horror series, whether it be Friday the 13th, Halloween, or Nightmare on Elm Street, gets a video game that actually appeals to fans and gamers? After the decades of shit that’s been shoveled our way, we deserve better! I know some of us would straight up kill someone for a good psychopathic horror game (see what we did there). Why hasn’t our nightmarish dream been realized?

Well, that time has finally come: a REAL Friday the 13th game will soon be upon us, and with the success that Dead by Daylight had we can hope to see some great mechanics – particularly with its use of asymmetrical gameplay.

Asymmetrical gameplay isn’t used often, and when it is it often requires fine tuning. Evolve’s asymmetry was clunky and awkward, and the fanbase fell off quickly because of the price and lack of gameplay/content. Dead by Daylight, which was much more reasonably priced, unassumingly released its beta to wild success -players jumped on board immediately and have faithfully remained as more patches and content have been released…for free. Dead by Daylight proves that this type of gameplay can be done well and can bring in a huge following, even with those not fans of the horror genre, simply due to great mechanics, incentives, and never forgetting that a game must be fun for it to succeed.

Escaping the clutches of a homicidal psycho maniac? Apparently this is a common way to spend a Friday night!

A good horror game series is hard to develop and produce without becoming trite and pointless. The original Nintendo Friday the 13th performed horribly, and fans of the films have not seen a game since then. This new title aims to resolve some of those previously existing issues and give gamers what they’ve always wanted. And did gamers want it? Well, the crowdfunding campaign alone speaks for itself. Friday the 13th game’s Illfonic attained their original goal within one month back in 2015. The game was jointly funded by the websites Backerkit and Kickstarter with over $1 million in donations raised.

With the gap in time we have witnessed and the funding that so many fans put forth, one would think that Illfonic has devoted the necessary time to create the game that all the backers wanted. Despite the time and funds, however, horror stories of crowdfunding gone wrong aren’t in the too distant past. Can Illfonic make the game of our dreams that will forever haunt our nightmares?

Luckily, it looks like Illfonic will deliver; the new Friday the 13th game appears to have everything horror fans are simply dying for. It will be a survival horror where players are pitted against a PC that controls Jason Voorhees. A cult classic character murdering some stupid teenage counselors from yesteryear in the true-to-film fashion we’ve all come to know and love (and fear)? Sounds like a solid game! Admittedly, the gameplay footage has been a bit vanilla. But the right idea is there and there’s no reason not to be hopeful.  If the gameplay ends up like what we have seen in the alpha footage, we can expect some white-knuckled, edge of your seat fear that will drive the gamer to level up their counselors so that Jason won’t murder them in his infamous style.

Just watching this footage makes me realize how terrifyingly realistic the game actually is. Not so much in graphics, although sweet baby Jesus are they better than the NES days. But in that familiar increase in heartrate, small rush of adrenaline, and sweaty palms (sorry). Calm down, run away, and try to distract Jason as much as you can to survive; honestly, you’re already dead and just don’t know it. Good luck, fellow counselors; as a fan of the series myself, I’ll be there alongside everyone else, fleeing from terrible danger.

Shit, I think he is already here! I need to run awa-

title.rendered: Psychology Terms We Know Thanks To Video Games

content.rendered:
Like a lot of Psychology majors, I am not a Psychologist; that doesn’t mean, however, that I don’t use what I learned. In fact, all of us utilize basic tenets of Psychology every day – what is the Scientific Method but observing an event, forming a hypothesis as to why it happened, careful analysis, and then reaching a conclusion based off presented data? We use the Scientific Method when studying human behavior, whether it’s a researcher attempting to discover the root of Autism or you trying to figure out why that tinder match won’t message you back. To go a bit deeper, learning how to analyze data and seeking general trends is a great skill to develop when it comes to marketing, sales, finance, and other fields in various industries.

Going into finance comes with the added bonus of being able to analyze your massive student debt!

But one doesn’t have to understand the mountains of research in various branches of Psychology to see that observable and measurable human behavior exists all around us and, when a particular stimuli is introduced, specific criteria is met, or certain events occur, humans tend to react in one way or another. These patterns have been so consistent over such an extended period of time that, when the stimuli, criteria, or events are recreated in a clinical setting, researchers have observed the behavior that happens naturally time and time again and have concluded that humans “just do this thing” because “that’s what humans do”.

For example – we know that children learn through imitation thanks to a very famous study by Bandura. Children were placed in a room with an inflatable clown-shaped punching bag appropriately named Bobo. One group of children was left alone in the room while the other group watched as an adult mercilessly flogged poor Bobo and then subsequently left after their apparent rage-filled therapy session. As researchers observed (presumably through a window or two-way mirror), both groups of children would land adorably ineffective punches on Bobo, but the group that watched the adults go Fist of the North Star proved more aggressive than those that were left to their own devices. In other words, when children watch the behavior of those around them, they mimic it because that’s how they learn – the hopes and dreams of our future rests in the hands of tiny humans that are unable to critically think about why they do what they do.

In their capable, dog-food-eating hands.

Devising and conducting a study in order to test a hypothesis takes a lot of time, and that time could be used to do something more fun, like play video games. Since a lot of video games feature human characters, they tend to follow a lot of human patterns and therefore exemplify a lot of Psychological research already out there. Of course, not the bits where people fight dragons or zoom through procedurally generated disappointment, but the parts where…well, here’s a list of those parts:

 

The Bystander Effect

In inFAMOUS, you’re a totally normal guy who suddenly has crazy-awesome powers of electricity thrust upon him after a blast that wiped out thousands of people and reduced your once-thriving metropolis to ghetto anarchy. There’s always enemies abound, but you’re fine because you have those aforementioned powers. The NPCs, on the other hand, aimlessly walk around throughout the city, wishing they had taken that vacation time Betsy in HR had been telling them they should take because their hours capped and they stopped accruing them six months ago.

Anyway, while most of the NPCs are completely mobile, a few of the NPCs are on the ground, presumably dying from that freaky blast that ravaged the town. While the protagonist kinda-sorta understands that they’re sick or something and that he has the capability to heal them should he so choose, the plethora of “healthy” NPCs shouldn’t have the foggiest clue as to why there’s random people lying about in the streets. For all they know, these guys either have the plague or are participating in the largest “help, I’ve fallen and I can’t get up” flash mob this side of the Mississippi.

But that’s the thing – the army of clearly able-bodied NPCs doesn’t bother figuring out why a few of their fellow citizens are ill or even attempt to help the weaker ones, choosing to walk right past them instead. Sometimes, they even walk right over them and go on about their day, presumably drowning out the cries for help with their evil laughter and immoral thoughts.

“Can’t stop, gotta text…EVILLY!”

Right?

Actually no. This is called the Bystander Effect, which dictates that the more people present, the less likely we are to help a victim. According to Psychology Today:

“Social psychologists Bibb Latané and John Darley popularized the concept following the infamous 1964 Kitty Genovese murder in New York City. Genovese was stabbed to death outside her apartment while bystanders who observed the crime did not step in to assist or call the police. Due to another phenomenon called social influence (where individuals in a group monitor the behavior of those around them to determine how to act), each onlooker concluded from their neighbors’ inaction that their own personal help was not needed.”

In other words, the NPCs took one look at the guy on the ground, saw that no one else assisted, and decided that “well, since no one else is helping this guy out, guess that’s just not a thing we do”, proving that humans are terrible, pixelated or not.

 

Lake Wobegon Effect

Here’s something that happens all-too-often in Skyrim; you’re plodding along, minding your own business, actively avoiding progressing in the main quest, when a dragon suddenly flies overhead. Anyone else would find themselves standing in a puddle of their own urine before being promptly devoured by said dragon, but you’re not anyone else – you’re the dragonborn. You can talk their talk, and you can walk their walk, and you can definitely walk up and down their asses every minute of the day (which is about how often dragon attacks in Skyrim occur).

Naturally, news of your badassery spreads, and soon you acquire notoriety, property, and government/guild positions throughout the region. Despite being known as “the Nordic messiah/only guy capable of killing dragons”, there are those that would challenge you in battle – sometimes even right after they’ve been within the general vicinity of your death-defying feats that can, again, really only be deemed as miraculous. “Some guy just wasted a dragon? He’s about to get his ass beat” are really popular last words in Skyrim. Is it just shitty AI? Are entire bands of roving Thalmor blinded with jealousy over your sweet shouting skills or just plain blind?

Bitches be trippin’.

While all the above could be true, and those bitches could most certainly be tripping, there’s another Psychological phenomenon that is illustrated here: Illusory superiority, or the Lake Wobegon Effect, in which individuals overestimate their own qualities and abilities relative to others.

The Lake Wobegon Effect is named after the titular fictional town where “all the children are above average”. Perhaps Skyrim should have been named after that town as well, because everyone and their dog likes to think that they can take on the Dovahkiin and win. It’s understandable at the beginning of the game when the word hasn’t traveled yet that this random guy shouts followers off mountaintops for fun and, when he gets around to it, defeats dragons out of annoyance rather than necessity, but once the player has logged thirty or so hours (or one sitting), the NPCs should really start catching on. They never do of course – the protagonist could be at level eight or level eighty and it doesn’t matter; bandits still seem to track the dragonborn down and ambush him from time to time, shouting empty threats and insults before they’re mowed down in an almost comical manner.

Okay, sometimes it’s definitely comical.

 

Aberrant Salience

Fallout is by no means the only game to feature randomized items, but it sure does take the cake when it comes to the sheer amount of them. While there are some unique items that are worth collecting or weapons that do so much damage that it would be foolish to explore the wasteland without them, there’s a fine line between “collecting” items and “hoarding” them.

Fallout 4 makes players take that line and shoves it so far up Bethesda’s ass they’ll see another Elder Scrolls game before that line sees the light of day again.

We’re not really sure what we said, but what we mean is that it’s really easy to think that every item the protagonist comes across seems useful in some way. While this applies to all games, this franchise takes it a step further in that there’s a) so many goddamn items & b) the whole post-apocalyptic setting really sets the tone for this illusion of scarcity and literally anything seems valuable.

Just consider for a second the environment outside the context from the game and think about how life would be if this was reality. Bottle caps, once considered trash, are now currency. Bottled, clean water would be worth its weight in gold if that was still a viable measurement of value. And don’t even get us started on settlements – in order to build actual ones, reusing everything suddenly becomes less a frivolous goal and more of an actual survival strategy.

Except Beanie Babies. You will never have a use for Beanie Babies.

What’s striking about this obsession to pick up literally every single item is that NPCs don’t see the reason to do the same. You may look silly overencumbered, but at least all that wood, oil, and asbestos will keep you warm at night! After all, these items are universally super important, right?

It’s true that the items are used to build settlements and whatnot, but let’s get real – there comes a time when items are no longer being picked up because they’re needed and moreso because it’s a compunction. What’s interesting is this, coupled with the fact that NPCs rarely bother collecting even .1% of what the protagonist does, illustrates Aberrant Salience*. Found in Schizophrenic patients, the Oxford Journals describes it as:

“the Aberrant Salience model proposes that psychotic symptoms first emerge when chaotic brain dopamine transmission leads to the attribution of significance to stimuli that would normally be considered irrelevant”

Even though neither the protagonist nor the player is Schizophrenic (we’re guessing with that second one, no judgment here), an analogy can still be drawn. The Sole Survivor wanders the wasteland doing various quests and collects items along the way. There are usually NPCs along the journey, and these NPCs are often capable of bending over and picking up the same items the character picks up – the question is, why haven’t they? They could be lazy and would rather someone else come do it or run their errands or save their settlements, but Aberrant Salience would dictate that the items in question were never important to begin with. NPCs weren’t picking up the items because they were physically incapable – they simply couldn’t be bothered to collect what amounted to garbage. A dopamine imbalance makes the patient protagonist believe that those items are important, thereby obsessively collecting everything that they come across.

Doesn’t stop us from collecting said garbage, of course – it just makes us feel bad while we spend hundreds of hours doing it.

no ragrets

 

Psychology aims to uncover mysteries about human behavior, from the most complex of problems down to minute details. Video games are often modeled after people and the AI can therefore reflect human behavior – sometimes accurately, sometimes broken, and often comical. A deeper look into our beloved games reveals the best and worst in human nature and brings us a little bit closer to understanding our species, which amounts to highly evolved apes. Who said video games can’t teach us anything?

*While we totally get that the stimuli in question is referring to psychological stimuli that is intangible, we wanted to use our Psychology degree for something as pertaining to video games. Is that a crime?

title.rendered: Even Sex Can’t Sell Vives: Why Porn Won’t Save VR

content.rendered:
Remember Suicide Squad? The hype was real: every human alive was stoked based on the trailers. We hailed it as the future, the comic book film that’d show studios not everything had to be Marvelized. It was the movie we deserved and needed right now.

And then it came, the world said ‘meh’, and we’ve spent every day since wondering who TF cast Cara Delavigne.

“How did I get here?”

That may be the story of VR in 2016. Earlier this year, you couldn’t find a tech or gaming outlet that didn’t spend a thousand hours per day heralding Oculus Rift and HTC Vive and the rest as the wave of the future, speeding us to our Ready Player One OASIS-based future.

But last week, the bean counters delivered grim news: sales of both major headsets had ‘flat lined’, with growth slowing to .1% for the Rift and a total goose egg for the Vive. What’s more, a Steam poll reveals only .18% of users own a Vive, and just .10% a Rift.

Not exactly the summer blockbuster everyone expected.

But with all the nail-biting going on in tech boardrooms, some are opining that an unconventional yet historically-dependable hero might just save the platform:

Porn.

Pros: Now no one at work can see your screen. Cons: Everyone at work can still see your Johnson.

You’ve seen the headlines, even if you won’t admit to seeing the product: adult film producers started pumping out X-rated VR films before the headsets were even available to the public. Which, if you know your history, isn’t unusual.

The pornography industry is always one of the first to adapt to new technology. As soon as a new media platform develops, they’re immediately putting bouncing boobies on it. It’s odd to think of a ‘disreputable’ industry being such a tech pioneer, but adult content is always amongst the first into new mediums. When a caveman first carved some lines on a stone tablet, a skeezy neighbor probably ran over and showed him 100 tablets he’d already carved of naked caveladies.

Ugh, even more unrealistic female beauty standards.

Pornography is also widely credited with making-or-breaking mediums. The VHS vs. Betamax example from a hundred years ago is the most popular example: Sony’s Beta could only hold 60 minutes of film, while a VHS could record three hours. When it came to porn, that was literally more bang for your buck.

Eventually, Sony banned Beta-porn altogether. This became a problem economically, as Americans are a horny bunch: by the end of the 1970’s, half of all videotape sales in the US were pornographic. And since you didn’t spend your childhood rewinding The Sandlot on Betamax, we all know how this story ends.

The explosion of the internet also owes a debt to bumping uglies. Estimates on just how much of the web is NA-17 vary, but suffice to say it’s a lot, and it’s always been that way. In the mid-‘90s, all you needed was a ‘100 Free Hours of AOL’ CD and a credit card, and a few clicks later you could watch unlimited action to your *ahem* ‘hearts’ content. But when you were done, maybe you checked the baseball scores, and then tried that shopping thing your coworkers were talking about, something called ‘Ebay’. And you saw that it was all really cool, even without the naughty bits – thus the internet exploded faster than anyone ever imagined.

And now, 20 some odd years later, we’re on the virtual reality horizon, and people are thinking the pornography industry will once again define the technology’s rise and development.

It won’t.

That’s why you don’t watch VR porn at work; you watch it on your phone in your car at lunch like everyone else.

Firstly, VHS’ victory over Betamax was a battle between competing platforms. Pornography played a large role because the former was more accommodating to it technically, and in the end, simply allowed it. VR is a monster all on its own – there’s no competition, it’s not fighting against a bizzaro Catholic-values VR. So if there are any parallels that can be drawn from the ‘70s video wars, it’s that a developer’s tech and platform better play nice with sex, or your competitors will put you out of business. Most companies have read their Sun Tzu and won’t make the same mistake as Betamax – although Sony is again being wishy-washy with its stance regarding X-rated content on PS4.

But the rise of the internet, which also didn’t have any traditional ‘competition’, is more interesting. Because if porn was able to radically accelerate the development of a major platform like the WWW, shouldn’t it have a similar effect on the VR revolution?

Again, no.

In the ‘90s, when pornographers cleaned the sticky stains off their photos and tapes and loaded them on the web, they didn’t need to change anything. A picture of Pamela Anderson looks the same on an Apple monitor as it does in Playboy. 2 Girls 1 Cup looks the same on VHS as it does on [redacted].

*soft piano music plays in the distance*

VR porn is a completely different animal. There are new cameras and new technology to start, but also a whole host of new creative challenges that producers must overcome. Reports from early tests are mixed, with the most common praise being immersiveness. But more often than not, the (un)lucky testers come away with conflicted feelings.

First, there’s the ‘uncanny valley’ syndrome – when a virtual experience is very close to reality, any noticeable flaws become magnified and psychologically more disturbing. Imagine being incredibly immersed in a POV scene – how 99% of VR porn is currently being filmed – and you fully believe this blonde is on top of you, when all of the sudden she leans in and, per lens warp, just grew like Apache Chief. Or, how about if ‘your’ arm moves into frame, even though you did nothing with that arm IRL? If ‘immersive’ is the big selling point, these videos aren’t there yet.

title.rendered: Hey, Listen! The 5 Worst Video Game Companions

content.rendered:
Why do developers think companions are a great idea? Don’t get me wrong – there’s the occasional amazing sidekick that you really can’t imagine playing without, like Tali’Zorah or the Companion Cube, and it’s really hard to screw up a horse, like Agro or Epona. But too many games seem to throw in a half-baked character that is sorely underdeveloped or incredibly annoying that you’ll do your best to beat it without them, if possible (we’re looking at you, Lydia).

But even Lydia had her moments – at least she was sworn to carry your burdens. There are much worse offenders out there that deserve to be banished to the annals of forgotten video game history, no matter how much they’re loved for incorrect reasons. Why? Because they’re terrible. Here’s five of them:

  1. Edward – Final Fantasy IV

Edward is the Prince of Damcyan who also happens to be a (spoony) bard in his free time, which should be relatively none since he is a prince (and has important princely things to do, like run a kingdom and whatnot). He is embarrassingly terrible in battle and never truly becomes useful, except for when he plays his harp from a safe distance 1,000 miles away to end the Dark Elf’s Magic. In battle, he does no damage and has the appropriately useless “hide” ability. He might as well hide the entire time he is in the party because he is a worthless coward who was responsible for his lover Anna’s murder. So not only can he not fight, he actually ends up getting people killed, which is the exact opposite in what adventuring parties tend to want in a companion. As a prince who was raised in nobility and received an education based around the idea of protecting his people, how could he let Anna die? No wonder Tellah wanted to seek revenge on the weak turd that put his daughter six feet under – he’s a crappy prince who ran away to play his harp too much.

 

  1. Riki – Xenoblade Chronicles

This terrible companion only goes by one name: Riki. Riki is a legendary hero from the Frontier Village on Bionis. An annoying voice, people, and prophecy plague this companion on his journey, because of course a great JRPG on the Wii has to have irritating characters that are directly involved in the plot. It’s like a prerequisite or something. Anyway, he’s a bumbling idiot that eats too much and is infuriatingly accompanied by eleven children that will enrage the crap out of the player during every cutscene (guess no one taught this guy to wrap it before he taps it). If that wasn’t enough, Riki likes to reminisce about parts of his life that are not only irrelevant but drone on for so long that the player may forget why they started playing Xenoblade Chronicles in the first place. It’s almost like the developers thought “well, we’re here, why not give an already annoying companion even more awful traits and flaws?”.  Riki, seriously, please shut the hell up (and invest in some condoms!).

 

  1. Ashley Graham – Resident Evil 4

In Resident Evil 4, Leon S. Kennedy is sent to Europe to save the American president’s daughter, Ashley. The game never does elaborate on exactly how she got kidnapped, but judging by her Britney Spears-esque costume and her general uselessness, it’s doubtful it was a goodwill-mission-gone-wrong. Turns out not only is she an aggravatingly annoying little girl who is practically a walking stereotype of a damsel in distress, but she doesn’t do a single thing to protect herself the entire game. You’d think an adult who’s been on this green Earth for twenty-something years would develop a sense of self-preservation, but at no point does she ask for a gun or knife to protect herself from various cultists and monsters. Nope, she’s good, she’ll just hide in a box or run down a platform completely out in the open (which are two wildly different things, mind you). Even when she is being grabbed at by ravenous, murderous enemies, she makes no attempt to get away or dodge any kind of attack. I suppose she does get some credit for getting the radiation surgery to remove the plagas from her chest, as that would hurt terribly, but not much, because it doesn’t do enough to override her general inability to be useful.

 

  1. Navi – Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time

HEY LISTEN! Navi just has to be on the list; everyone hates her (if you don’t, you’re wrong. Sorry). I mean really, she doesn’t help Link as much as impedes his every move during the beginning, middle, and, well…all of the adventure. She tries to give the player “helpful hints” but actually stops gameplay every 5 seconds to HEY, tell the player LISTEN something new that he/she has probably already concluded WATCH OUT. Unfortunately, the Zelda series is known for having annoying helper characters, such as the Owl or Fi, but Navi always seems to come to gamers’ minds when thinking of the most irritating of them all. HEY LISTEN, Ocarina of Time is an incredible Zelda title (and largely considered the best in the series), but Navi just sucks. HEY!

 

  1. Cait Sith – Final Fantasy 7

The premise and gameplay of Final Fantasy 7 are great: stop Sephiroth from being reborn into a god with endless power using the magic from the black materia to destroy everything everywhere. Everyone remembers the crew of FF7 and how each character affects the story, like when Cloud gets molested in a questionable bath house or when Aeris dies (TOO SOON). When it comes to Cait Sith, most gamers agree that the only effect…it? he? had was being terrible – not only in battle but during the story as well. While visiting Gold Saucer for the first time, he immediately decides to join the quest to save the world and gives Aeris that awful fortune telling her she is going to die (thanks for that nugget of joy, Cait Sith). Cait Sith can best be described as a giant, ugly, fat polygonal Moogle serving as a beast of burden to a malnourished cat that desperately needs attention. Cait Sith is controlled by a Shinra Turk named Reeve Tuesti, initially stealing from Cloud and the party to help Shinra then threatening the group, forcing Cloud&Co.’s hand when it wasn’t necessary. In battle, all of Cait Sith’s weapons and limit breaks are appallingly godawful to the point where players will refuse to use him. His stupidity is sprinkled here and there throughout the plot and every time he speaks, gamers wish there was a way to set him ablaze. Sith in Star Wars are cool but Cait Sith blows.

Did we miss some that really grind your gears? Let us know in the comments section!
