title.rendered: So You Wanna Work In Games: Audio Design

content.rendered:
So you wanna work in video games? Certainly the thought must have crossed your mind as you conquer enemy-filled dungeons or waste zombies/vampires/whatevs. Working in video games would definitely be a dream job, but…well, what would that job be? Programming? Writing? Marketing? Audio Design? Working in games doesn’t necessarily mean playing them…you’re either creating them or supporting those who create in some way. All video game-related jobs are important, and games as we know them wouldn’t get made without everyone doing their part.

Here’s a part that some of you may or may not have considered before: Audio Design. It permeates literally everything in gaming – the very first video games featured beeps and boops, while the games of today have more advanced sound effects – all of them holding the possibility to become iconic. What is the noise you hear when Mario gets a 1UP? How does Kirby sound when he is inhaling deeply? And what about the individual, unique cry of each Pokemon? Certainly many sounds flooded your mind as you remembered ones that you’d heard time and time again. Each effect, noise, cry, and everything in between was created by an audio designer in the process called audio design.

I have cool friends, and one of those friends happens to be an audio artist for Electronic Arts (EA). Literally living all my childhood dreams and more, Michelle was gracious enough to accept an interview on what’s like to work in audio design and how one might be able to follow in her footsteps (we highlighted some key points we thought were really important!).

 

So what is audio design?

Audio design is the process of manipulating, generating, creating, and editing audio. Many people may not realize it, but a lot goes into audio design in a lot of things we hear everyday. Television, animation, movies, theater, video games, etc. Someone has to watch those golf games and make sure the audio is on par and meeting specs for television. Someone has to make sound for those explosions in the Michael Bay movies. And whether it’s someone going out and recording sound in the real world, doing foley, or mixing sounds together, it’s all a part of audio design.

 

How did you become interested in audio design? How did you even find out about it being a job?

I have always been tinkering around with sound. My whole family plays an instrument, so I grew up watching my mom play piano and organ and my dad play the drums. I also grew up watching my Dad play video games, and then my brother and I would constantly play video games. It was Final Fantasy 7 when I realized how much emphasis on sound there was on games. In addition to video games, I was raised on the violin and piano and was constantly in all the orchestra classes from elementary school to high school. It was in high school that I was introduced to Garage Band in my multimedia class and I was hooked. I was constantly putting loops together and making music. In college, as I was figuring out what I wanted to be my first year, my mom called me and was super excited. She said she found out that the University of Utah was offering a degree in video games. Of course I was intrigued! I’ve been playing games my whole life. So, I signed up.

The University of Utah offered an engineering path and an art path. Sadly, no audio path was available. I took the art path and studied 3D modeling and animation. Going through it, I realized these games I was helping create couldn’t just be silent, and the video game degree didn’t offer any audio design courses. It was at that moment I decided  that I would take up audio design; I began teaching myself what I needed to to know. At the start, I was just getting free sound samples online and mixing them together, but the more I progressed the more I learned. Later on, I found out about Fruity Loops and I started using that to make music. Further down the line, someone introduced me to East West and Sounds Online – from that point on, I was obsessed. I bought the Gold Strings and from there my obsession really took off. I was suddenly the audio designer for almost all the games being made in my classes and I became known as “The Sound Girl”. I loved it and continued doing audio design wherever I could.

The University of Utah also offers a masters degree in video gaming, so I decided to take that to hone my skills more and connect with more people. At that point, I was still on the art side of things and was focusing on animation and becoming an animator. I found out the film school offered one sound course, so I jumped right on that; still, it was only one course, so I kept forcing myself to learn and to help in all the projects I could. In my last year of the masters degree, my counselor e-mailed me saying that Electronic Art’s studio, Mythic, was looking for audio interns. I was so excited I quickly applied and…I got it! They said I sounded so excited about the job that they knew I’d work hard. I moved to Virginia and worked with Mythic for a few months. When I moved back to Utah to get married, a year later I was called up and was told the Electronic Arts office in Salt Lake city needed an audio designer and I was able to nail the job. I have been working there since.

 

What steps did you have to take in order to get a job in audio design? School? Extra-curriculars? Internships?

The University of Utah sadly doesn’t have a course for audio design, so I am all self-taught. There was one class at the U of U for sound, so I jumped on that right away. However, I mostly watched YouTube tutorials, messed around in Fruity Loops constantly, and did as many projects as I could. When I was being interviewed for Mythic, I studied their games and made sure I had questions to ask. When I asked why I was hired, my boss said that the two people he hired (myself and another person) were the only ones who sounded excited about the job and asked questions. He knew I was ready to learn and work hard.

 

Describe a typical day in the life of a audio designer.

For an audio designer for mobile video games, I come into work, attend stand-ups where I hear what people are working on (lets me know if something is ready for audio), then I get to my office and see what animation, VFX, or UI need audio cues. I usually get a playblast of animation or in-game capture of VFX. This is where the fun starts! I have a library of hundreds of audio cues that I can edit and master together for our game’s needs to make what I think the animation or VFX or buttons sound like. Once I get something together, I get feedback and tweak it as necessary. I also need to make sure it’s in specs (not peaking, the EQ is fine, etc).. From there, I render them out, put it in our middleware (I’m currently using FMOD Studio), and then put it in our game engine and hook it up appropriately. If it’s something too complicated, I work with our programmers to get the audio hooked up.

 

What is your favorite part about audio design?

The creation: I’m building what our games’ sound like, what the environments sound like, what everything sounds like! It’s really fun being able to listen to the games we design and go, “I made that”.

 

What is one thing that surprised you about audio design?

How easily it can make someone feel. When I worked at Mythic, I remember making sounds of a zombie whale and what it sounded like when you stuck your hand in its zombie scars for research: pained whale noises followed by squishing. It not only made me feel sad and weird, but everyone who played that quest remembers the zombie whale and what it sounded like!

 

What would be some good skills to learn for an aspiring audio designer?

Don’t worry about making your own sound library; there are so many out there that it shouldn’t be your first focus (unless it’s what you truly intend to focus on). If you want to make sound for video games and you came to me for an interview, I’d first look to see if you have a demo reel. I want to see if you can make something come to life with sound: how loud it is, how soft it is, did you mix it well, etc. Then, specifically for video games, I’d see if you know FMOD and/or Wwise as well if you know Unity or the Unreal Engine. Then I’d see how excited you are about the job, and if you ask me questions. Lastly, I’d see if you can work well with people and know how to take feedback and criticism.

 

What school subjects should an aspiring audio designer focus on? Should they learn specific programs that are relevant to the field? Which ones?

Take any sound courses you can. If you want to focus on music, then take music courses and composing. If you have the money, apply to a school that focuses solely on audio design. You’ll mostly need to learn how to use an editing software like Pro Tools or Sony Vegas and master plugins like iZotope Nectar, Ozone, Alloy, Waves, etc.

 

Is there a lot of competition in audio design, or is this a job no one thinks of?

Sadly, I particularly think that it’s not really thought of and therefore is a very competitive workforce because of that. There aren’t a lot of audio designers in the world compared to programmers or artists. But don’t let that deter you! Work hard and make connections!

 

If you could go back in time and tell yourself something about audio design when you were just thinking about getting into it, what would it be?

That this would be my calling and to focus on it. I was so close to being an animator and put so much focus on it that I missed out on audio design a lot.

 

Any fun projects you’re working on?

I’m currently working on the mobile games “Minions Paradise” and “Pets Unleashed”.

 

Anything else we should know?

When you’re playing a video game, listening to TV, or watching a movie, try to listen to the audio design! So much is put into making what things sound like!

 

So, is audio design right for you? Is that something you’d be interested in? Start like Michelle did – look into classes, teach yourself programs, and get involved with as many projects as you can. Maybe you’ll be the next addition to your favorite video game company’s sound team!

title.rendered: Could We See Another G4?

content.rendered:
There are no shows on cable television for gamers anymore. Reruns of shows that had nothing to do with gaming ended up on G4 (Cops, Nightrider, or Lost) and killed the once great channel off. These shows didn’t appeal to the demographic of “gamers” and could have been aired on any number of broadcasting companies were added for rerun use and pure mediocrity. So we even though we know why G4TV failed, we saw some great original shows broadcasted (until the station decided to give them the axe).

No wait, come back! Can’t we talk about this?

Are we able to create any other gamer-centric channel without management mucking up everything before the channel truly takes off? Could anyone spend the time to actually create quality content that would travel through the appropriate filters before being aired? The answer is yes – and with the use of Twitch and YouTube, personalities of all kinds have been able to demonstrate their ability to entertain and provide great substance. But, even with these great online options, it seems that the gaming community is falling into the same trap G4 couldn’t avoid.

Take ScrewAttack as an example for new online entertainment. Screw Attack began in 2006, bringing forth the podcast SideScrollers which was created by their parent company Rooster Teeth (Red vs. Blue). We had a different medium for gaming entertainment and things seemed to go well in the first few years between the podcast and shows that were aired. One major difference between using YouTube and Cable TV as the entertainment medium has changed the way we as a society watch and intake our entertainment. All of a sudden we have an online gaming show that doesn’t have a single commercial about Tide Bleach or how Geico will save you from offending a caveman, or whatever.

Survival of the thickest skin, Neanderthal.

This was majorly impactful on how the community viewed TV and videos, as we no longer were required to watch needless commercials that had zero relevance to G4TV. Slowly over the years, more and more people have strayed away from cable TV and found other entertainment mediums (Netflix, Spotify, YouTube, etc) because the consumer now has a say in what they watch and pay for. This power over what the viewer watches and takes in became a major reason why G4TV failed; no one wanted to pay for extra channels when all they were going to watch was HBO and G4TV.

Twitch is the finest example of this idea: Twitch launched in 2011 as an internet streaming client where gamers could watch a host play and beat games that they streamed. Paying $5 gets you extra benefits within a channel and supports an entertainer doing what they know and love. This idea is the polar opposite of cable TV: instead of paying one fee for channels in bulk, you pay for a single channel instead of multiple channels – most of which you will never even look at. Ideas like this could never thrive on network television because, as a station, they have to pull in a certain number of views per show and channel to make their mark. Jane Doe on Twitch just wants $80 donated so she can get a better microphone to provide better quality entertainment on her stream. Viewers don’t mind throwing her a buck to two to support the cause. Seeing Twitch and YouTube thrive will change the way we view our entertainment as gamers, and really, as a society.

Here is where we run into issues with Network TV crossing lines with YouTube shows and personalities. ScrewAttack was purchased by Fullscreen in 2014. Why does this matter? Well, if you research some of FullScreen’s regularly scheduled programs, they include Dawson’s Creek and Saved by the Bell. Granted, they rarely show those 90’s cringe-nostalgic shows that really knew how to reach into your belly and cause you to vomit, but it’s not hard to see ScrewAttack go down that same road due to the same type of poor and misguided management that ultimately ended G4TV. This is something the gaming community fears the most: seeing their entertainers get slowly purchased by larger companies, only for the entertainment to change to what the larger companies standards are.

Oh great, big networks, look – you’ve gone and made Dawson cry again.

There is a balance YouTubers and online personalities try to have between making a living and providing entertainment. James Rolfe, the Angry Video Game Nerd, has done this quite successfully with Cinemassacre. Worth nearly $100,000, he has properly executed a way to make a good living and provide quality viewing with each new episode he creates. The Angry Video Game Nerd has been around for over 10 years and has not fallen down the same trap at G4TV did.

Could we see another G4 or G4TV? One could argue that we are currently living in it, between Twitch and YouTube’s success and their ability to bring in more viewers every day. Consumers now have the choice in what they watch, listen to, and read every day, which is significantly different from 10 years ago. Gamers can pay $5 to support an entertainer they like and get extra benefits with the subscription, along with chatting with viewers who are there for the same reason. Gamers get to watch as retro and new games are reviewed and played and are there on the ground level watching it live and contributing. People still want G4TV to come back, but really, it already has and it’s greater than ever before. Sit back and enjoy – we as a society no longer have to pay for the entertainment and television we didn’t care about; we now get to pay for what we truly want. What a time to be alive.

title.rendered: Game Developer? Investor? Gamer? We Want You!

content.rendered:
What is EquityArcade?

You probably know us as the website that churns out some pretty interesting articles on video games, gaming culture, and the industry. Maybe you like watching our streams and videos with our talented media folks. Perhaps our social media channels keep you entertained with memes, pixel art, and <insert wit and creativity here to round out a rhythmically pleasing list of three>.

Well, good. Because we are all that.

But we’re so much more.

EquityArcade is truly a one of a kind crowdfunding platform that allows gamers to invest in video games. Sure, there’s kickstarter and gofundme for getting a game off the ground, but this is different. We’re building a community of gamers, investors, and developers that benefits all parties. Game developers are able to raise funds to create their games, and gamers are able to build equity in the companies that they’ve interacted with and have grown to love.

Quite simply – we take “owning a video game” to the next level.

In the spirit of building a community, we’d like to open up our publishing department to allow for guest writers. If you’ve been reading our content thus far, you know we have a thing for investing/money matters, a hard-on for indie titles, and video games are bae. We’d like to see user-submitted content from the following:

  • Game developers who want to show the world their game(s)
  • Finance peeps who know a thing or two about investing/money matters
  • Gamers who have an opinion and love writing about it in an entertaining way

Do you sound like you’re any of those things listed above (or some super-human combination of all three)? Awesome – we want you!

Here’s some info you need to know before you get started*:

  • We wanna hear from real-live, 100% organic, grass-fed gamers, investors, and developers – content farms need not apply.
  • Articles must be a minimum of 500 words; do your best to not exceed 3,000 words, please (we suffer from adult ADHD and can only pay attention for so lo-hey look, a distraction!).
  • Google docs preferred, but we’ll take a Word doc if that’s your thing. It’s like when you ask the server for Diet Coke and they ask if Diet Pepsi is okay. Like yes, we’ll drink it, but we’re going to bitch about it for ten minutes until our food comes.
  • We can’t publish plagiarized content. Standard, really.
  • We’re not a game review website, so we’re not looking for game reviews on any given single game. Straight-up game reviews are not going to be published, sorry (we don’t even let our staff-writers do this, so it’s not you, it’s us).
  • Get creative – we can’t publish the same article twice (google your topic idea + Equity Arcade to see if we’ve done it before). Also fairly standard.
  • Submitting an article does not guarantee we’ll publish it, but it does guarantee we’ll read it to ascertain if we can (I mean, you went to all that trouble to write an article for little ‘ol us, sooo…).
  • If we accept an article, we’ll gladly put your name on it (obvs). But from then on out, it will be published on EquityArcade.com and therefore (all your base are) belong to us. Sorry, no take-backs!
  • If we accept and publish one of your articles, we can’t guarantee that we’ll publish every other article you send (gotta make sure they all hit the criteria, yo).
  • If you submit an article and we let you know that we can’t publish it, the article is yours to keep (we still love you no matter what <3).
  • Articles must go through an editing process to destroy unnecessary commas and run on sentences in order to be accepted and published. Yes, destroy (but we’ll do our absolute best to keep your voice intact – we were just raised by English teachers is all).
  • Guest writer =/= employment, but an EquityArcade article on your portfolio sure is neato and your crush will totally be impressed.
  • Payment is negatory, good buddy – at least until further notice. But you have our love that burns with the white-hot intensity of a thousand suns and we’re pretty sure that can keep anyone warm at night (we don’t use blankets anymore because of it. A little annoying honestly, because we had this one blanket that we really liked since an ex made it for us. While the relationship is long-since over, the blanket remained as a snuggly reminder of our days spent together, laughing, sharing secrets, making sweet, sweet love, and…oh God…excuse us for a moment, we have something in our eye).
  • We feel that this is a chance for writers who want to get their name out there and build their portfolio or for a gamer who wants to see if writing is for them.
  • We really believe that this is a great opportunity for game developers to shine – we’d love to promote an awesome indie game, but there’s one caveat: we’re not selling anything. Don’t try to entice readers with hackneyed sentences like “what are you waiting for? Buy today!” because that’s not gonna fly around these here parts. Instead, tell us why your game is unique or interesting. Seduce us with concept art/screenshots. Lure us closer with stories of unanticipated challenges you experienced. Hold us tighter with some advice for aspiring game devs. Pull our hair with…you know what? This is getting too serious. Just write a non-salesy article about your game and why it’s cool while talking about some interesting things you learned along the way. We love reading about cool indie games and the fascinating stories surrounding their development. You could say it’s a turn-on (call us, maybe?).

Did you read all that? We hope so. There’s honestly no way for us to tell if you read it or not, but we did put it out there so you’d know what to expect from us (and so you don’t get mad at us for not doing something that we didn’t promise in the first place).

We understand if writing isn’t your thing. That’s cool and we respect that. We still want all of our readers to stay with us as we continue to grow our crowdfunding platform. Because really, where would we be without all of you? Bring it in for a group hug, everyone!

Please send all submissions to submissions@equityarcade.com

You stay classy, planet Earth!

title.rendered: Indie Game of the Day: Prey for the Gods

content.rendered:
Major Kickstarter successes are hard to come by… and it’s even harder to witness the emergence of a game worthy of the success it sees.

But I hope that is what No Matter’s Prey for the Gods, today’s Indie Game of the Day will become – a major success story through and through. With its Kickstarter campaign skyrocketing past $500K, this action survival certainly looks to be the next big hit.

I had to reveal the trailer as early as possible this time around. It’s just so damn good. The snow, the graphics, the music, and the art direction… all these aspects can easily force a jaw to drop with its gravitational pull. And yeah, know that this game is absolutely 100 percent indie; it’s totally real, and this game is heading our way.

So besides the setting being cast in an eternal winter wonderland, what can one expect out of Prey for the Gods in terms of the story and the gameplay?

Well, for one, you’re a lone wolf who is sent to the edge of a dying world to uncover the reasoning behind the perpetual winter. You’re only equipped with clothes and nothing else. Matters only take a turn for the worse with the existence of gargantuan dangers that will not hesitate to murder you in the most gruesome way possible (being devoured is a good start).

The core feature to look forward to in Prey for the Gods is the colossal, epic battles with climbable giants. In other words, a feature that most definitely takes influence from the cult classic Shadow of the Colossus. Hell, if you haven’t noticed, even the art style is influenced by the title. It’s absolutely phenomenal.

Furthermore, you can’t forget about these included features, all of which – blended together, anyway – will make Prey for the Gods stick out like a sore thumb:

  • Dynamic snow terrain (instant desire right there, as I fucking love the snow).
  • Intense survival gameplay.
  • Exploration of temples that are loaded with both secrets and treasure.
  • Dynamic day and night cycles, alongside dynamic weather.
  • Non-linear gameplay that will allow you to choose who and how to battle.
  • Fallen hero locations. These heroes come with items ripe for scavenging, providing you with a survivability advantage.
  • And quite the intense musical score.

But what about the gameplay? Are the battles similar to the battles ingrained in Shadow of the Colossus? Well, sort of. The battle system takes influences from not just Shadow of the Colossus, but also Deus Ex, DayZ, and Bloodborne. In other words, holy shit that’s a combination to anticipate, packed within tight controls executable with either keyboard or gamepad. It features the typical, “simple to learn, difficult to master” schemes, especially when you’re facing brutal giants that ultimately require creative strategy. That’s right, the game will work against you as you try to eradicate the giants. How so? Well, your weapons can break and the arrows are finite, so be careful.

Currently, Prey for the Gods is accepting PayPal donations, so if you want to support this game, it’s time to throw some sweet, dolla dolla bills at it. We’re looking forward to its progress! In the meantime, you can marvel at the second official trailer of Prey for the Gods.

Prey for the Gods will launch someday for Steam, Xbox One, Mac, and PC.
